PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the Australian Labor Party conference on privatisation, which will be held next Monday. I ask: Does this conference have the power to veto government policy on privatisation?
—The Australian Labor Party national conference makes the policy for the Party; it makes the platform for the Party.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. Do I take it from that answer that the conference does have the power to veto government policy on privatisation?
—I have nothing to add to what I said in my original answer.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he has noted recent reports of the high levels of salary paid to executives of many of Australia's major enterprises. Do these reports indicate cases in which some of those salaries have increased by 11 per cent in the past year? Do they show that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, whose chief executive gets a mere $290,000, performed better last year than Westpac Banking Corporation, whose highest paid executives get nearly $2m a year? Can the Minister indicate whether ordinary workers, whose wage movements are conditional on progress and structural efficiency, are entitled to be confused or frustrated by these reports? Is it not a fact that these ordinary workers have accepted unprecedented wage restraint over the past seven years in the national interest and in the cause of economic reform? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether business executives have shown the same restraint over the past seven years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm, as stated in the first part of the question, that high levels of salary are being paid to executives in major Australian companies. That has been reported in recent days in the press. As to the second part of the question, yes, in some cases the increases are in excess of 11 per cent. I have no reason to question the newspaper report about the Commonwealth Bank-Westpac comparison. However, I am not in a position directly to confirm those figures mentioned in the newspaper report.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether workers are entitled to feel frustrated, many of them, through their organisations and in their own right, express frustration at what seems to be a growing ethic-if `ethic' is the right word-in which some employers are saying to their workers, `Don't do as we do; do as we tell you to' or, `Everyone must tighten his belt, but we as employers or senior executives won't'.

Senator McKiernan also asks whether I can confirm the levels. A quarterly survey of executive remuneration is published by the consultancy firm Cullen Egan Dell Australia Pty Ltd. Cullen Egan Dell is an international management consultancy company operating in Australia, Europe and the United States of America. It is a specialist in executive remuneration and executive job search. It produces a two part survey which shows, in the first part, figures for senior management, which includes senior staff across a range of professions, including finance, personnel, data processing and engineering and, in the second part, figures for the senior executives of companies.

These are not good figures in the sense that they deal not with the total remuneration package but just with the salaries component. Anyone who follows executive remuneration knows that the total package is what is negotiated for not just that element that deals with salaries. Taking the salaries part alone, there is a significant gap between the salary increases in senior executive remuneration and the increases in average weekly earnings since 1983-84.

For the year to the end of the June quarter 1990, the senior management group had total remuneration increases of up to 8.3 per cent and the senior executives' total remuneration rose by 11 per cent for the same year compared to an increase of 6 per cent in the average weekly earnings of full time adults. In the last year ended June, a significant gap occurred.

Over the six years to June 1990, senior management remuneration increased by 71.4 per cent; senior executives salaries rose by 89.2 per cent, and average weekly earnings for full time adult workers increased by 47.3 per cent. Over that six year period of survey, there was quite a considerable opening in the gap between the two levels. I might also say that it was expected by some pundits that the latest data would show a slackening of executive salaries due to economic conditions. The latest survey shows a continuance of the same level of growth in executive salaries.

I conclude on the basis that a picture is better than a thousand words. The graph from the sources surveys of Cullen Egan Dell, which I am holding up, shows pay comparisons from the year 1982-83 to 1989-90. The top line with the steepest incline represents the senior executive level, the middle line represents the senior management group and the line indicating the lowest level of increase represents ordinary workers in Australia who have practised significant--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the cameras on?
—If the camera can get a close up, well and good. Ordinary workers have practised significant restraint over the whole period.
—Can the document be tabled?
—The Minister has been requested to table the document.
—Mr Deputy President, I table the document.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to a speech he made in Melbourne over the weekend in which he suggested that Israel should now open a dialogue with the Palestinian Liberation Organisation (PLO) and not use the Gulf crisis as an excuse to delay this dialogue. I ask the Minister: Does he believe that serious consideration can be given to an Israel-PLO dialogue before the Gulf crisis is resolved? Is there not an obvious danger that the resolution of the Gulf crisis would be tied to the issue of resolving the differences between Israel and the PLO? Was it not Saddam Hussein who tried to propose a linkage between the Gulf crisis and the Palestinian issue, for which he was roundly condemned? Why does Senator Evans make this comment now when, only last week, he said in Estimates Committee B, `Obviously the prospects of a formal dialogue between Israel and the PLO have not been improved by recent events'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill's question might be slightly better founded had he looked at the actual language which I used rather at than newspaper reports.
—I did.
—Page 16 of the speech?
—No, I read the speech. It was not based on a newspaper report.

—Look on page 16. In the speech I referred to the desirability of Israel not using the PLO's reaction to the Gulf crisis as an excuse for not seeking to resolve the Palestinian question for a variety of reasons which I spelt out. In the course of making that particular point I said, on page 16, that any approach to the resolution of the Palestinian issue would require a spirit of statesmanship and, of course, a willingness to compromise on the part of the Israeli Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I went on to say this:

If that statesmanship is to be productive, it will necessarily involve dialogue with Palestinians, both inside and outside Israel and the Occupied Territories, who have been directly associated with the PLO.

I chose those words carefully. It is becoming increasingly evidently the case that it may well be necessary for more attention to be placed on those Palestinians within the country, particularly those who have come to exercise a substantial leadership role since the Intifada, with the present PLO leadership having less attention in the future, particularly in the aftermath of the Gulf crisis.

But it does not make any particular sense to go on applying the kind of test that the Israeli Government has so far insisted on applying; namely, that it will not enter into dialogue with anybody who has PLO affiliations, either as a member of that organisation or being very directly associated with it. The point that I am making is that the resumption of some form of dialogue, an attempt to resolve the Palestinian question, is not one that can be endlessly further delayed, because of the demographic time bomb and a whole variety of other considerations which I spelt out, and that dialogue will need to be with key Palestinian leaders. It may not need to be quite as much in the future as has been the case in the past with the familiar figures of the PLO leadership who have so comprehensively discredited themselves in the present crisis, but it will need to be with Palestinian leaders.

One simply has to go on assuming for the foreseeable future that those leaders, particularly those within the country that it is going to be worth talking to, are people who have had such associations in the past and will no doubt continue them in the future. It is a subtle but important distinction, from the way in which Senator Hill put the question, that I am making.

I made very clear in the speech that there can and should be no direct linkage between, on the one hand, the resolution of the Gulf crisis and, on the other hand, the resolution of the Palestinian issue or, indeed, a variety of other issues like the Lebanon one, which are endemic problems in the Middle East. Not only would it be wrong in principle to seek trade-offs in that kind of way but it would, in our judgment, be quite counterproductive to seek to draw that overt linkage.

However, as Secretary of State Jim Baker has himself said, there is absolutely no reason why an appropriate resolution of the Gulf crisis should not itself be a `springboard' both for the achievement of some more comprehensive and satisfactory security arrangements in the Gulf-and, indeed, the whole Middle East-and also for the resolution of those conflicts, in particular the very bitter and divisive continuing conflict with the Palestinian people. There is absolutely no reason why we should not think of an ongoing process.

Indeed, as I made very clear again last night in making this speech, it may well be that Israel can approach compromise, can approach the negotiating table, with a greater spirit of confidence in getting a secure and guaranteed outcome from that process as a result of the new world order that is conspicuously being put into place and being demonstrated, as well as being tested, by the present Gulf crisis.

So, in terms of the willingness of the international community to come to the aid of besieged or attacked small countries, in terms of the bridging of divisions that have traditionally in the Middle East made the resolution of conflict that much harder-in particular the division between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-and in terms of the new and very effective role being played by the United Nations, there is greater cause for confidence than for pessimism about the possibility of a peace settlement actually being productive, upholding and not, in fact, undermining Israel's long term interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to the intervention of HMAS Darwin in the Gulf in firing warning shots to bring about the stopping of the Iraqi vessel, the Al Fao. I ask the Minister: Was this action justified? Was it within the rules of engagement as announced by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time late Friday night or early Saturday morning eastern standard time, the HMAS Darwin, in company with the United States frigate the USS Brewton, intercepted an Iraqi tanker. Initially that tanker failed to stop and failed to heed any of the appropriate steps and the USS Brewton fired some warning shots. The tanker still refused to stop. Ten minutes later the Darwin then fired some warning shots, and the ship stopped at that stage. A boarding party embarked, at which stage the tanker again took off, but following the intervention of another Australian frigate and a British frigate the ship eventually halted. A boarding party from the Darwin and the Brewton boarded, carried out the normal verification procedures and then allowed the frigate to continue.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst this particular incident, being the first to involve boarding, has attracted a lot of publicity, it is simply a normal procedure in the multinational naval forces operating in the Gulf. I believe that the Australian role in it was carried out efficiently and with all the propriety of our rules of engagement, and I am quite pleased with the performance of Australian ships and personnel in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce relates to the Minister's knowledge that we are in the period of public consultation over the multifunction polis (MFP). Is the Minister aware that one of the first acts of public consultation during this period is a two day conference to be held in Sydney-I stress, in Sydney-with no speakers opposed to the MFP and costing those attending $995 each? Is the Minister aware that even a set of papers from this conference will cost almost $500? Is the Minister aware that the MFP Committee has called tenders for a $150,000 contract to convince the people of South Australia that the MFP is good for them and that the success of this public relations exercise will be judged and rewarded according to how much its efforts change public opinion in favour of the MFP? Is the Minister aware that tenders have already been called for work to commence on the MFP site? Does the Minister consider this a fair way to conduct public consultation so as to discover the will of the people of South Australia? If not, will he attempt to influence his State colleagues in South Australia to conduct open, unpressured dialogue with the public so as to discover whether the people of the State really do or do not want the MFP?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, Senator Coulter has a muddled set of information in his head. He started off by talking about a seminar in Sydney which is sponsored by some consultants and has nothing whatsoever to do with the community awareness program over the MFP. It a commercial operation run by a group of consultants in Sydney. I repeat, in case the honourable senator is not clear on this matter, that it has nothing to do with the community awareness program relating to the MFP. That was a little story that lent a bit of weight to an otherwise weightless question.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the second and third parts of the honourable senator's question, I am fully aware that work is being done on the Gillman site, the proposed site for the MFP in Adelaide. That has to be done. If it was not done Senator Coulter would be screaming his head off and putting his environmental hat on. It has to be done and it is being done by the South Australian Government.

As for the question of the calling of tenders for public awareness projects in Adelaide, I believe that that is taking place. If the honourable senator wants further details in relation to that matter I will have to get them for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. Is the Minister not to be a speaker at this conference in Sydney costing $995? If the Minister is participating in a commercial venture, as he defines it, what role does he play in relation to the public consultation process, which I would have thought was to discover what the people of South Australia want in relation to the MFP?

—The MFP is a national project, not just a South Australian parochial project. It happens to have its principal site in Adelaide. I think I have accepted an invitation to speak at the conference in Sydney. I assume some people will pay $995 to attend--
—Who gets the 900 bucks?
—Sadly, I do not know where it goes, but not to me. It is a private or commercial initiative to discuss issues relating to the MFP; that is a good thing.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is there an air transport blockade against Iraq? If not, could Iraq effectively avoid the shipping blockade by engaging in an airlift-using Iraqi and stolen Kuwaiti planes-reminiscent of the 1948 Berlin airlift? Are there any signs of increased Iraqi air transport activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no organised air blockade of Iraq at present in the sense of some aviation equivalent of the stop and search process that is being applied on the water. While the possible need for such a blockade to ensure that sanctions are not broken by flights into Iraq has been raised, including I think on one occasion by British Foreign Secretary Hurd, our assessment is that the existing sanctions regime and its implementation are proving to be sufficiently effective so as not to make that really necessary. It should be appreciated that the potential for Iraq to try to circumvent the embargo by air is very strictly limited. This is because measures other than a strict and formal military blockade can be used and are being used to close off opportunities for sanctions busting by air. Such measures include not allowing direct air services, not allowing overflight, and not allowing ground facilities to be provided to aircraft which might be engaged in breaking the sanctions. Such measures, in whole or part, have been implemented by many countries and have certainly caused a major reduction in the activities of Iraqi Airways. Australia does not have any direct air links with Iraq, so the question has not arisen about us implementing any such measures, but we would do so if it ever became appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: It is conceivable that Iraq could seek to mount a major air transport effort to circumvent sanctions, but this would require the cooperation of Iraq's neighbours, and certainly a number of other countries as well. The international community would respond, I think, very quickly to any evidence of such cooperation. We are not aware of any indication whatsoever of increased non-military Iraqi air activity. There are Iraqi Airways flights to Amman, plus some special evacuation flights. Otherwise, Iraqi commercial flights are simply not operating. We will continue to watch very closely the situation in this respect, as will, in particular, the member countries of the United Nations Sanctions Committee. I can say that Australia would support any internationally agreed measures which are regarded as necessary to ensure the further effectiveness of sanctions in the event that it became apparent that the aviation route was being significantly applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to reported statements by Mr Hogg, the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, describing the Government's uranium policy as contradictory and in need of revision. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's statement that the Government's policy is not logical? Does the Government rule out the possibility of opening additional uranium mines?
—I do not want to comment on either Mr Hogg's views or the Prime Minister's views, but let me say I do not rule out the possibility of a change in the Government's uranium policy.
—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister, then, what further is required to open additional mines apart from appropriate environmental guidelines?
—If the policy is going to be changed, it would require a decision to change it. It, therefore, requires a decision.

—My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 is now four years old and is under review in a number of forums and committees. Can the Minister inform the Senate what further steps are being taken to evaluate the effectiveness of this legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The affirmative action Act becomes, at last, fully operational this year with the phasing-in of the last band-the third band-of those employers employing between 100 and 499 employees. That requires them to submit reports to the Affirmative Action Agency on the affirmative action policies and plans for those particular companies. Given that the Agency now has reached the full phasing-in of the original Act, it will be paying more attention to evaluating how the Act has been performing.

ANSWER.PARA: It will identify those factors which assist in the achievement of affirmative action policies, as well as those factors which inhibit the realisation of those goals. It has not been appropriate, until now, to conduct such a review during the phasing-in stage because the information provided would have been only partial, not full information based on a proper operation of the Act. I might add that the director of the Agency is required, under the Act, to conduct a review.

The review-which should be completed by the end of 1992-will be based, as I said, on how the Act runs, but there are three major projects already under way which will help to finalise that review. One is a three-year survey of attitudes to and knowledge of affirmative action and equal employment opportunity amongst private sector employers, employees and their representative bodies. Another is a series of case studies conducted over three years of the experience of 10 companies in developing and implementing their affirmative action programs. That project will involve companies which have performed particularly well under the Act. Thirdly, there is a detailed evaluation of the processes and impact of affirmative action implementation in a sample of higher education institutions.

Other areas being addressed as part of the effectiveness review include an assessment of the impact of affirmative action implementation on enterprises; analysis of the labour market reform programs that we have-that is, the award restructuring element and how it impacts on women's employment status; and an evaluation of the operations of the Affirmative Action Agency itself.

The review process, as far as the Government is concerned, will be a very open one. We want key interested parties to be given every opportunity to participate. It is important to the Government that the review of this important social and employment policy be effective. As a government, we are committed to affirmative action. We want to see it work properly. We want to see a workplace, or a work force, not in which there are any second-class citizens but in which there is appropriate representation and recognition of the rights of all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask my question of the Minister for Defence. I refer to the decisions by France and the United Kingdom to increase their troop commitments in Saudi Arabia and, also, a report from Washington that the United States of America will want an Australian presence in Saudi Arabia in the event that conflict breaks out. I also note that Australia has now announced the dispatch of a medical team to the Gulf to work with a United Nations ship-a decision, incidentally, which appears to have been made about a week ago when Parliament was sitting. I ask the Minister: Is there any plan to send further forces to the Gulf area; under what circumstances would such a commitment be considered; and what circumstances led to the dispatch of the medical team?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit puzzled by Senator Durack's reference to the medical team. I included that in my answer to Senator Vallentine. I cannot say whether Senator Durack was in the chamber at that time and picked up that point. It was well and truly in the public domain last week.

ANSWER.PARA: In spite of what might be reported out of Washington, the Australian Government has not received a request for any further commitment of Australian Defence Force assets to the Gulf region. As Senator Durack knows, we have committed three ships. The subsequent commitment of a logistics team and a medical team in support of those ships in no way could be considered to be an escalation of the Australian commitment. Having committed ships, it was inevitable that we would have to provide a logistic team to make sure that the ships were supplied and a medical team for the treatment of both injury and sickness. So at the moment we have had no request to commit ground forces to the Gulf region or escalate our forces there, and I am not going to speculate any further on whether such a request did emanate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is he aware of any Australian companies that are directly or indirectly involved in breaching the economic blockade of Iraq? What action could be taken against such companies if indeed they do exist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not aware of any Australian companies which are involved directly or indirectly in breaching the economic blockade of Iraq. It would require a pretty adventurous company to seek to do so, given the range of legal measures and, of course, policy decisions that we have put in place. It is worth retailing them, I think.

ANSWER.PARA: On 7 August, all permissions under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations were withdrawn by the Minister for Defence, effectively blocking all exports of military related equipment to Iraq. The Australian Customs (Prohibited Exports and Prohibited Imports) Regulations were amended on 8 August to prohibit the import of goods from and export of goods to Iraq and Kuwait. Austrade in this respect has directed its staff not to engage in any activity in relation to the expansion or promotion of Australian trade to Iraq.

The Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations have been amended to stop the movement of funds in and out of Australia to or from the governments of Iraq and Kuwait, their agencies or nationals, without specific approval from the Reserve Bank. Again, migration regulations, effective from 31 August, ensure that prospective visitors to Australia who would be likely to engage in commercial or other activities involving Iraq or Kuwait in breach of United Nations (UN) Resolution 661 will be precluded from obtaining visas.

The relevant government departments and authorities are alert to the need for strict enforcement of these measures to ensure adherence to the UN sanctions and are acting accordingly. If there is an attempted import or export of goods in breach of the Customs regulations, it is worth reminding people that the relevant goods are subject, under the Customs Act, to forfeiture to the Crown.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, and it is in four parts. Firstly, can the Minister inform the Senate what criteria were used to determine the proposed private equity levels in Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia? Secondly, why has the Government decided to sell only 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank but 49 per cent of the airline? Thirdly, was one of the criteria the quantum of the proceeds and, if so, was any analysis of the difference in the net proceeds of these sales done or was the only analysis purely what the 24 September national conference would cop? Lastly, does the Minister agree that the loss of once-off windfall proceeds of partial privatisation, due to offering less than an optimal level of equity, can never be recouped?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only comment on the basis of being a Minister who took part in some discussions of these matters, both as a member of the Government and as a member of the Australian Labor Party. Let me begin by saying that the circumstances of each of the instrumentalities which the honourable senator referred to are quite different. The question of, for example, privatisation in relation to Qantas is a different question from that relating to Australian Airlines, it is a different question from that relating to Telecom and again it is a different question from that relating to the Commonwealth Bank. They are all different instrumentalities.

ANSWER.PARA: If one is privatising in pursuit of ideology, one sees them as all the same. If one is privatising in the pursuit of efficiency and national interest and so on, one sees the issues very differently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us the differences.

—`Tell us the difference', says Senator Alston. Well, there is an enormous difference between privatising Telecom and exposing its monopoly to competition. In my view, there are enormous reasons for having a publicly owned telecommunications carrier and the same reasons do not apply to a domestic airline. There are very different reasons for doing each of those things.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the question of the quantum of proceeds referred to in Senator Campbell's question, again one looks at each transaction or proposed transaction. But it is not the quantum of the proceeds which is an important criterion in terms of what the Government is doing or proposes to do. The important criterion is to enable each of these instrumentalities to compete vigorously in an international market or a domestic market, as the case may be. To be able to do that they require further equity capital. That is the important thing, not the quantum of the proceeds. There may be, of course, significant proceeds in one or two of these things, but it is not the most important issue.
In regard to the question of loss of windfall proceeds, the answer to that very much follows on what I said about the quantum of proceeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to salinity levels in the River Murray and land degradation, both of which matters were raised at a recent Murray Valley League conference at Murray Bridge. Can the Minister advise what actions the Government is taking to address the issues of both salinity levels in the Murray River and land degradation? How much money is being spent on these areas in this year's Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As at least those on this side of the chamber will know, the Commonwealth is fully committed to addressing the problems of salinity, drainage and land degradation and the management of land and water resources in a manner which is economically viable and ecologically sustainable. That is a commitment throughout Australia, but it has no greater pertinence perhaps than in the Murray-Darling Basin area.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has put in place a comprehensive package of initiatives and programs to address all of those problems in this area. Initiatives which target as a high priority issues of salinity and land degradation include the Murray-Darling Basin initiative itself, the Federal water resources assistance program, the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation, the national soil conservation program and the program for one billion trees.

The Commonwealth has placed particular emphasis on the Murray-Darling Basin initiative with an allocation of $10.3m this year compared with $6.7m in 1989-90. The initiative was developed jointly by the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and promotes planning and management of the natural resources of the Basin for efficient and equitable sustainable use.

The key components of the initiative include a national resources management strategy which sets up a framework for community and government to address the current severe environmental degradation of the Basin. Funding for the second year of this program has been increased from $3.8m to $5.7m. The salinity and drainage program is receiving a total of $4.6m this year. A total of $38.9m has also been allocated this year under the federal water resources assistance program to the States and local government, and some of that will flow into the Murray-Darling Basin.

Those programs specifically targeted for the Basin under that item are: $7m for salinity control on the Basin and $1.4m for water planning and conservation, including rehabilitation of bores in the great artesian basin. I can go on and refer-
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been required to detail a quite comprehensive set of programs. I was trying to bring the answer to a summary conclusion by saying that together with the States the Commonwealth has sponsored some 500 land care groups in the area each of which are vitally important in mobilising land holders in managing the problems for themselves within a Basin-wide plan and hopefully within regional and farm plans for the area. The total amount being spent for 1990-91 in that area is $10.9m and as well there is $21.8m for 1990 for the national soil conservation program, some of which money is going to the Basin. The one billion trees program administered by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has of course the target of one billion trees by 2000. This year's allocation is $5.1 million compared with $4.6 million last year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RAVENSHOE: ASSOCIATED PLYWOODS SALES PTY LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, firstly, to inform the Senate whether the Government has made an offer of continuing financial support to the receivers of Associated Plywoods Sales Pty Ltd to ensure the continuing operations of the timber mill at Ravenshoe in northern Queensland. Is so, upon what conditions was payment to be made conditional? Secondly, is the Minister aware of a warning by the receivers that unless government funding is continued the mill will be dismantled and sold off piecemeal, which will mean the death knell of the town of Ravenshoe? Finally, can the Minister advise whether the Government would support a proposal by the citizens of Ravenshoe for the formation of a cooperative to buy the mill as a going concern from the receivers?

—I am not certain of all the details, but of course I am aware that the mill has been in financial difficulties for some time. I am aware that a receiver-manager was appointed some time earlier this year. I understand that those financial difficulties were caused by cash flow problems from elsewhere within the group which was running the mill. I think that we gave $8m worth of assistance to that mill as part of a package. I think that was the correct decision given that Ravenshoe was one of the towns most directly affected by the decision to list for World Heritage a very large area of the wet tropics of north Queensland.
—How many votes do you get in Ravenshoe?
—Unlike Senator Alston, I do not have to do things for votes. I can tell honourable senators that I have not spent much of my time chasing votes in Ravenshoe.
—The situation is changing.

—Senator Boswell did not get too many either; he must have been there. I do know that the receiver-manager did meet with the Minister, Mrs Kelly, in June this year to advise that the sawmill was continuing its operations for the foreseeable future. I think Mrs Kelly would agree that the best way for us to act at the moment is to negotiate some temporary assistance to keep the sawmill operating until we can get a long term solution. Whether that long term solution is via the mechanism that Senator Macdonald suggested of a cooperative from people in Ravenshoe or by another viable, financially strong company buying in, I am not yet sure. But obviously, given the extent of the Government's investment, it is something which Mrs Kelly will keep high on the priority list and under constant review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it the case that married pensioners will receive only half the compensation for the introduction of the $2.50 pharmaceutical charge that will be provided to single pensioners? If so, does this mean that the Minister is advocating that husbands and wives can benefit from sharing their drugs in the same way as other expenses, such as rent and food, can be pooled? What will the Minister do to address these anomalies? I also ask whether he will rescind the Treasurer's nonsensical Budget Speech claim that:

QUESTION.PARA: These arrangements mean that for all those facing the $2.50 charge for the first time the charge will be at worst income neutral.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation for married couples is that they are getting $1.25 each as distinct from $2.50 going to a single pensioner. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I thank you and honourable senators for this opportunity to address the Senate. I stand here today as a Queenslander and a Liberal. I extend to both the people of Queensland and the Liberal Party my thanks for the confidence they have placed in me. In particular, I wish to thank my fellow Queensland senators-Senator Parer, Senator Macdonald and Senator MacGibbon-and their staffs; and I thank Senator Macdonald for his kind words last week and commend him on his excellent maiden speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland Liberals have a proud record of commitment to electoral justice and public accountability. I have no doubt that this played a large part in our electoral success. We now have four Liberal senators from Queensland for the first time.

In 1973 I attended a meeting that changed the course of my life. It was arranged by doctors who deeply cared to hear the then Minister for Social Security discuss his plan for heath care in Australia. His plan spelt out the mechanisms of control of the profession I love and the destruction of many of the principles which we doctors knew were the mainstays of the care of our patients. I decided to do something about it. And today I stand before the Senate, while the originator of that process now grazes-nay, some say `gallops'-on the Elysian fields of Yarralumla, blissfully unaware of the havoc he and his successors have wreaked on my profession and on the health care of this nation. Just as havoc has been wreaked by Labor, repair can come from the Liberals.

The fact is that expenditure on our health care has been virtually static for the last 13 years. Of all the countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, only Australia-together with Austria-has failed to keep pace with the consumer price index in its spending on national health care. We once had a standard of health care second to none, yet the ceiling has been set on spending for 13 years. We have a greater number of people requiring health services and a greater ability to service those needs. This is even more serious in view of the fact that the provision of health services and the standards of those services depend on the finance made available.

With increasing community demands and static government spending, standards must decline. The result is a public hospital system that is overcrowded and underfunded, while resources in private hospitals are under-used. Waiting lists for elective surgery-particularly in Victoria and New South Wales-have lengthened dramatically. On top of this, many privately insured patients occupy public beds. In 1989 privately insured patients occupied 25 per cent of the total acute patient bed days in public hospitals. Inevitably, this has affected all public hospital patients and those waiting to be public hospital patients.

Under Medicare, health insurance has become a luxury. Rates have rocketed and tax concessions have gone. Immediately before the introduction of Medicare, 61.5 per cent of the population had private health insurance. In March last year it was only 45.8 per cent-a drop of 30 per cent in the proportion of the population holding health insurance. Today, only 30 per cent of our people in Queensland have private insurance.

Given that all political parties accept the principle of community rating-that is, that the well pay for the sick, ensuring that everyone can buy health insurance at the same price-there are enormous financial pressures on the health insurance industry. The majority insured under the present system are those who make the most demands on it, so, naturally, costs spiral. Health funds are only attracting 35 per cent of Australia's young people. Private insurance premiums have risen 72 per cent in the last three years.

The paradox is that every one per cent who opt out of private health insurance cost the public sector $80m a year. The health tax-euphemistically called the Medicare levy; 1.25 per cent of income tax-funds only one-fifth of health expenditure. If one adds the outlays from the States and the private purse, the levy accounts for less than one-tenth. The major contributor is the taxpayer by way of general revenue. Today's health system is in serious trouble and, unless we do something urgently, tomorrow's will be very much worse.

We have a worrying set of new problems. The first is Australia's ageing population. One hundred years ago the population was one million with an average age of 20. Today it is 17 million, with an average age of 31. In 10 years time it will be 20 million, with an average age of 36. By the year 2000 it is estimated that two in every seven Australians will be over the age of 50. We now have the greying of Australia. Two-thirds of health expenditure is on the over 60s; one- quarter of health expenditure is directed towards the 3.8 per cent of the population aged 75 and over. Even without these changes, the cost of national health care will escalate dramatically.

Secondly, we must appreciate the continuing impact of changes in medical technology. Just as members of this Senate have experienced in their own lifetimes the significant advances in communication, television, computers, facsimile machines and satellites, we in medicine have seen even more dramatic advances-computerised tomography (CT) x-ray, ultrasound scanning, magnetic resonance imaging, renal, liver and cardiac transplantation, ear implants, joint and lens replacement and coronary artery surgery, to name but a few. Genetic engineering is on track for the future.

While the increase in life expectancy has primarily come from the virtual elimination of infectious diseases and alteration in lifestyle, there is no doubt that the quality of life has been enormously enhanced by these procedures. The effect on health care expenditure has been dramatic. The use of ultrasound and CT scanning has doubled every two years. In 1983 there were 75 CT units in Australia. Today there are 230.

Consider also the cost of individual procedures. Bone marrow transplants and liver transplants are estimated to cost the community $100,000 each with no estimate for ongoing expenditure. There were 4,000 coronary bypass procedures performed in Australia in 1984, 6,000 in 1988 and an estimated 8,000 this year. With the aged proportion of the population growing all the time, one can only guess at demand levels in years to come.

Thirdly, the continuing cost burden of pharmaceuticals must be addressed. The high price of some of the life saving wonder drugs of the 1940s led Australian governments of both political parties to develop schemes to provide free or subsidised drugs. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) was the final version. In 1982 total expenditure was $688m. In 1990-91 it is estimated that the cost will exceed $1.5 billion, despite increases in patient contributions and changes in availability of drugs under the scheme. The recent Budget announcements do not address the long-term consequences of these cost increases.

Fourthly, changes in the type of health services available to meet changing patterns of disease will continue to have a significant impact on health costs. Disease patterns are constantly changing. The most obvious example is the AIDS epidemic-a disease which was not even on the horizon 10 years ago and which will require an expenditure of $77m this year alone.

The demand for screening is burgeoning in the community, and not only for AIDS. Mammography has been clearly demonstrated as being efficient in the detection of early breast cancer and $14.7m will be spent this year. In vitro fertilisation (IVF) techniques have developed to the extent that one in every 100 births occurs as a result of IVF intervention.

Fifthly, no government can ignore the problems arising from the excess number of doctors in Australia. Between 1976 and 1986 the number of doctors increased by over 50 per cent from 21,200 to 32,800. As well as that, foreign doctors are migrating here. It is estimated that 350 medical graduates enter the country every year-the equivalent of the output of two Australian medical schools. There is now a low economic return for practising a professional ethic. We all know that the average family doctor adheres to the principles of hard work, high standards of honesty and integrity, and self-sacrifice. Excellence is demanded but not rewarded. Bulkbilling is encouraged and it leads to overservicing. The increased rate of bulkbilling is claimed as a measure of success when all it represents is exploitation of the system.

Entrepreneurs are encouraged to establish glossy 24-hour clinics to the detriment of the average family doctor. The greatest problem facing the medical profession today is its own low morale. Twenty years of government intervention in professional freedom have exacted their toll.

Finally, the decay in capital infrastructure resulting from a severe shortfall in capital investment in the public hospital system also threatens the standards of service. Public hospital capital expenditure was 7 to 8 per cent of recurrent costs in the 1960s. It is now down to 3 per cent and equal to that spent on private hospitals even though public hospitals represent 75 per cent of the total number of hospital beds in Australia.

What then are the solutions to the health dilemma? The major issues in health care delivery are frequently described as access, financing and quality. Politicians are concerned mainly about access, bureaucrats about financing, and patients about quality. Australian governments of both persuasions have been attempting to bring the costs of the health care system under control-unsuccessfully for the last 17 years, as is evidenced by the number and frequency of changes since 1973. There have been no fewer than six major changes in Australia's health care arrangements in this time. Similar efforts have been made in the United States of America and Great Britain resulting in any number of proposals, such as health maintenance organisations, diagnosis-related groupings for hospital reimbursement, and day surgery proposals. All are dominated by the aim of cost containment and all inevitably affect access and quality.

Medicare is failing and will continue to fail because state control is fundamentally unsound. It has failed in eastern Europe and it will fail here. The ageing of the population and demand and cost of technology and pharmaceuticals make it inevitable that privatisation will occur whether our political opponents like it or not.

The challenge is to ensure that privatisation occurs in the right way-that is to say, privatisation has to occur in a way that ensures we get the highest quality, up-to-date health services at prices the people can afford to pay. Cost containment has never been, and never will be, a solution to the problem of providing a high standard, contemporary health care system which allows equitable community access.

We have to get rid of the myth that government can underwrite unlimited first-class health care which is available at all times and which is cheap. There will always be an excess of demand over resources because of change. I believe we have to get back to fundamentals and base our system on several basic principles. It is an Australian tradition that access to all services-not only health care-should be open, and I do not see this changing. An Australian health care system must encompass this particular philosophy.

The first principle is that the care of the individual is paramount. The standard of health care should be high and there needs to be adequate financial incentive and professional freedom for health carers to pursue excellence. One cannot expect caring, compassion, time and kindness from government. The second principle is that there should be freedom of choice for the patient.

We as politicians, however, have a responsibility to ensure that a safety net exists for those incapable of providing for themselves and, acting on their behalf, to ensure that value is obtained for every dollar of expenditure. We also have a responsibility to the aged and infirm, the chronically ill, the young mothers and their children.

The answer to our dilemma is to retain a publicly funded system for those who need help, while providing incentive to individuals to care for themselves by insurance either directly or by the establishment of superannuation-type funds specifically allocated for health care costs in the future.

A publicly-funded system is also necessary in order to retain the very high standards of teaching and research that have been a hallmark of Australian medicine. Nothing is free. The alternative is rationing-there is no other choice. Rationing means allocating resources where the most good is achieved in terms of quality of life at the cheapest cost to the community.

This line of thought opens up the whole spectrum of questioning the economic viability of a range of procedures such as in vitro fertilisation, heart and liver transplantation and even coronary artery bypass procedures. Whatever we would like to think, there is a limit to maximum life expectancy. Life is a continual battle against death which we will all lose. Death is inevitable. A diminution in mortality from one cause will be balanced by an increased number of deaths from another cause. Even the elimination of cancer today would only lead to a theoretical increase in mean life span of about 2.3 years.

The days of measuring health care outcome by life expectancy are gone. The thrust for the future will be in the quality of life, not in quantity. Years of misdirected effort have seriously jeopardised our system of health care. There is little evidence that the system, as it is presently structured, will be able to cope with the demands confronting it over the next decade. This country must make some fundamental choices about the type and standard of health care we require in the future.

I come now to the second matter of great concern to me. The second event that has occurred over the last 17 years which has contributed to my decision to seek elective office has been the apparently deliberate attempt by the legislature to denigrate the importance of the family unit in Australian society. The effect of this has had a dramatic impact and it will flow on to the next century.

The Liberal Party believes in the importance of the family and that the standards of a free society should support family ideals. I believe that Australians have a responsibility to protect family life as the basis of civilised living and in the caring for young and old. Yet what has occurred? Children have become scarcer. They have become an economic decision for families. Children under 15 represent only 22 per cent of the population and they are expected to represent only 20 per cent in 10 years time. At the moment too many children who might be born are not. We are losing one in four unborn members of our population.

As well as ensuring a proper working environment, we need to do more to help the many mothers who would prefer to rear their children at home. Some recent surveys show that 80 per cent of young mothers would prefer to be full time home-makers while their children are very young. Instead of policies that discriminate against those who produce children, we must promote the sorts of policies that encourage and nurture families with children.

Today 51 per cent of married women are in the paid work force compared with 29 per cent in 1966. This increased proportion of women in the work force has been one of the most significant changes in the Australian economy over the past 25 years. This trend reflects both changes in community attitudes as well as changing economic circumstances. Where are the days when somebody could afford to be at home with the children-in a home that was not under threat of being resumed by the banks?

While these changes have been significant, they have been matched by other features of contemporary society. For instance, some 45,000 children each year see their parents divorce. There is no doubt that there is a social cost reflected in the number of divorces each year and the increasing number of single-parent families. We now have 77,000 homeless children. The cost is becoming greater each year. I see the family as fundamental to our society. I believe it is worthy of protection. It certainly should not be subjected to assault through the complacency of government. The Bauer report, prepared for the President of the United States, stated:

It is no accident that every totalitarian movement of the 20th century has tried to destroy the family . . . The essence of modern totalitarianism has been to substitute the power of the state for the rights, responsibilities and authority of the family.

The family is the main intermediary between the individual and the state. The Labor Government has done nothing with tax policies and discriminates against ordinary families. The family strengthens the individual against the state. It is time to call a halt to this trend.

All of us here in this chamber and in this Parliament are leaders. As such we have a responsibility to our nation to halt the slide in our already depreciating standards. I for one am going to stand up and be counted in support of the importance of the family unit in the care of children and as a refuge from the fragmentation of society. I am not so naive to believe that an appeal to moral values or adherence to the Ten Commandments will be successful.

Policies need to be implemented which actively and positively discriminate in favour of the family. I instance income splitting and a home-maker allowance as initiatives which must be given serious consideration. True, the problems we face are great. Instead of ignoring them we must recognise that every problem is a challenge. The greater the challenge, the greater the opportunity for success. We must be prepared to seize these opportunities. We cannot afford to procrastinate. Mr Deputy President, these will be my goals as a senator.

The philosophy of liberalism, in its approach to health care and families, provides the most convincing and humane answers to the problems I have outlined. My time as a senator will be dedicated to applying this philosophy in a very practical sense in the interests of my constituents, the people of Queensland and of my country. Thank you.
Opposition senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Sherry, I would remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in the chamber. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I extend my congratulations on your election to the position of Deputy President of the Senate; also, my congratulations to Senator Sibraa on his election to the position of President. I also offer my congratulations on the maiden speech of Senator Herron. I am not sure what it feels like to be the first person to give a maiden speech but I certainly know what it feels like to be the last.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with a great mixture of humility and pride that I give my first speech here today in the Senate. In particular, it is a great moment for me to be representing my State, Tasmania, and also for me to be representing my Party, the Australian Labor Party, yet again in government.

The State of Tasmania was discovered by the Dutch explorer Abel Tasman. He called the island Van Diemen's Land. Then he sailed away and it was largely forgotten. The next to visit Van Diemen's Land were the French explorers who left little but names again, such as D'Entrecasteaux and Freycinet. Van Diemen's Land was also on the visiting list of the Americans and the Russians, but they were beaten by the English, who, recognising Tasmania's geographical isolation, realised the possibilities of a penal colony to end all penal colonies. Over the next 50 years of first settlement, approximately 40 per cent of all the convicts that were sent to Australia were sent to Tasmania. In touching on the theme of Tasmania's geographical isolation, I would like to acknowledge and thank the Hawke Labor Government for continuing to recognise the difficulties that the isolation has caused for our State by ensuring that the freight equalisation scheme was retained in full and unchanged in the recent Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —In real terms?

—The freight equalisation scheme is of great importance to our State. In answer to the interjection, it was retained in real terms. I wish to draw the Senate's attention to not just the disadvantages that are created by Tasmania being an island State, but also the advantages. It is a State with a unique environment, a unique history and a unique cultural background. It was that background that attracted my parents to the State of Tasmania in the mid-1950s-my mother because she was an English migrant who had originally settled in Sydney and found the climate too hot to bear; my father because he wished to find a permanent position in radio and ultimately as a television announcer.

SPEECH.PARA: My mother was of Scandinavian-Swiss background. She was brought up in a fairly comfortable middle class family in the outer suburbs of London. Her family were committed socialists. Her father was an architect and a staunch pacifist who served four years in prison during World War I because of his beliefs.

My father, Ray, served in the other place as the honourable member for Franklin from 1969 to 1975 and for a few short years as the State member for the same seat. My father was born in Sydney, the son of Spanish-Irish parents. He was born during the Great Depression. The Great Depression was an era which caused enormous problems for most people in this country. For my father it was a particularly difficult period because he was orphaned at a very early age, his parents dying in a motor vehicle accident. My father's brothers and sisters were fostered out and he was never to see them again. As an orphan he had to struggle to feed himself and to educate himself, leaving school at the age of 14. When my father talked about the years of the Great Depression-and he very rarely talked about them-his comments were couched in terms of his determination to ensure that such events never occurred again on the face of this planet.

As I mentioned earlier, it is with pride that I speak here today, but it is mixed with sadness because my father, although he was aware that I was preselected for what is regarded as a safe position on the Senate ticket, was not to see my election to this place; he died late last year.

I would like to acknowledge the role that my wife, Helen, has played in supporting me through that particularly difficult period. I also acknowledge the support she has given me over the last five years in the various roles I have played in the political and industrial movement.

Clearly, it was the influence of my family that originally led to my interest in politics. I first stood for a political position at college in year 12 when I was elected President of my college. It was a noteworthy election for one primary reason-I was elected by 13 votes on Friday the 13th. Since that day I have always considered 13 to be my lucky number.

I went on to the University of Tasmania, where I majored in political science and administration. I was Secretary and Assistant Secretary of the Students Union. However, I was not noted for my academic study. Like many students I found going through university without financial support somewhat difficult. So at the end of my first year I obtained a full time night shift job at Wrest Point Casino. During those four years my life was a whirl of working at the casino by night, student politics by day and precious little study in between.

My work at Wrest Point led to my activity in my trade union. Appropriately, with a name such as Sherry, it was the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. In that union I was elected as State Secretary at the age of 23, after a four year struggle involving three ballots and two Federal Court hearings. I then spent 10 years as State Secretary of that union.

During that time I was involved in the traditional industrial activities that some would like us to be involved in and those on the other side would like us not to be involved in, including a position as a Federal councillor of my union and also as a national negotiator in a number of key industries in this country.

It was not just my union activity and industrial activity that led to my interest in politics. Over the last 10 years I have also been deeply involved in the hospitality industry in a number of areas, including a position on the board of management of the college of hospitality in Tasmania, as a member of the Employment and Skills Formation Council, as a nominee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and also involved in various training organisations, including the tourism hospitality training committee in my State. But it was in representing individual workers and protecting them against exploitation that added to and confirmed my belief that in our society individuals need protection, where appropriate, from those who have greater economic circumstances.

In addition to my family background and my industrial involvement, I have been provided with inspiration by a number of individuals in the political labour movement. I do not wish to comment on all of them, but I simply mention one who has been particularly important to me, and that is the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Clem Attlee. He led the British Labour Party for 20 years, and was Prime Minister for 6 years. He was a person not renowned for his great oratory but certainly was renowned for his discipline and his commitment to the labour and socialist cause.

Clem Attlee also led a government that could, quite rightly, be termed to have carried out the most revolutionary changes in any society in economic and in social terms in any democracy in this century. There were such changes as the National Health Act, the Education Act, the nationalisation of a number of key industries and, above all, the recognition that the United Kingdom was no longer a world power and the recognition that there was a need to reside peacefully over the conversion of an empire to a commonwealth of nations. Many of the changes that occurred at that time would not be relevant in today's society. But Clem Attlee and his approach to British society and to the British Labour Party provided an inspiration to me.
On my election to the Senate I take the place of Ray Devlin. At this point I acknowledge the work that Ray did on behalf of Tasmania, particularly those people on the north-western coast of Tasmania.

The election as a senator is slightly less vigorous than some of the previous elections I have been through. I have been a candidate not only in union ballots but also for the the State seat of Franklin. The only noteworthy event to me in the Federal election was being attacked by a dog and having it reported in the media under the headline, `Dog takes a nip of Sherry'.

There are two primary principles in the Labor movement that I believe in very strongly and I believe separate us on this side of the chamber from those on the other side of the chamber. The first is the Labor Party's absolute commitment to democracy. Shortly I will come to some examples to dampen the horrified looks of some members opposite. The other principle that I strongly adhere to is the Labor movement's determination to protect those in less fortunate economic circumstances in our society.

In terms of the Labor movement's commitment to democracy, I refer to a couple of examples. The first is the recent events that have occurred in Tasmania. As many would be aware, last year the previous State Liberal Gray Government called an early election. Its members discovered that 17 is not bigger than 18. But they would not give up office. They were determined to press on and demanded another election, having just lost one.

This sort of behaviour totally discredits our democratic system. Gray is still at it: he is still trying to have another election, calling on the Tasmanian upper House to reject Supply, not on the basis that there has been any economic incompetence or indeed any corruption-in fact, if one looks at the economic incompetence one sees that it lies with the previous State Liberal Government and if one looks at corruption one only needs to see that one of Tasmania's leading media magnates is resident in Risdon prison-but on the basis that a school is being closed or that a hospital is being closed. That is supposed to provide the reason for a fresh election.

The other example I wish to draw to the attention of the chamber relates to the events of November 1975. We all know what 11 November was traditionally remembered for prior to 1975. The only comment I make is that on that day I swore that I would never forget.

In terms of the economic advancement of individuals in our society, the Labor Party ensures that, at the appropriate time and in the appropriate way, the individuals in our society are protected from those in stronger economic circumstances. It is the Labor Party that, where appropriate, uses the State to protect individuals in our society. I wish to give an example of where I believe it is appropriate that that is carried out-in the area of industrial relations.

I note with interest that many of the first speeches of Opposition senators and honourable members in the other place were devoted to industrial relations. They talked of freeing the labour market of rigidities and restrictions. They talked of individual employers having the ability to negotiate freely with individual employees, onerous restrictions imposed by awards being removed, and no interference from third parties such as unions and industrial commissions. They said that, if this happened and individuals had the right to sit down and negotiate with employers on an equal footing, it would lead to a boost in productivity and everyone would be happy.

That is far from the truth. In reality, if we examine the bargaining power in any system such as that, we see that it is the employer who is in the dominant position. I draw the attention of honourable senators to an example in the hospitality industry. Imagine an employer having the right to negotiate with individual employees, one by one. The proprietor, flanked by his legal advisers, would call in the individual workers and engage in this process of collective bargaining. I submit that we know what the outcome would be. The employer would submit to the workers, `If you don't cop $6 or $7 an hour, you don't have a job; take it or leave it'. That is the sort of equity that the Liberal and National parties are arguing for in their industrial relations changes.

A range of problems is facing this country: the balance of payments; public sector infrastructure, including railroads and ports; severe regional unemployment in many areas; the distribution of wealth and the environment. I wish to touch on a number of problems associated with education and training. At present there are two stark ways in which we can improve the economic circumstances of this country: one is to decrease wages and decrease conditions in order to be more productive and the other is to increase the education and skill levels of our workers in order to increase productivity and output. I much prefer the latter.

However, there are in this country a significant number of problems in attaining that improvement. If we are to be a clever country, greater investment in training and skill formation is required. At present our investment in that area is mediocre by Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development standards. I draw the attention of the chamber to the Minimum Training Guarantee Act which was enacted earlier this year as an example of a way in which this can be encouraged. It is in the area of skill formation and training, the less glamorous side, if you like, of the education debate to which I wish to draw attention.

In this country millions of people are locked out of the education and skill formation structure. They are locked out because the training system in this country is not coherent, it is not portable and it is not interrelated. Some of the problems include a lack of appropriate formal training in many industries and a lack of access to training including the problems of funding, functional illiteracy and the apprenticeship scheme.

I still find it incredible that one of the major props for our training structure is the trade system-a trade system that is a thousand years old and in many ways acts as an impediment to training in that it restricts, by virtue of age, people being able to obtain apprenticeships. It also, I suggest, has acted strongly as a disincentive to females obtaining access to the trades system.

The example I have given in the trade area suggests that the structure of training itself does not provide sufficient flexibility for persons to enter and continue in training throughout their working lives. Training should be delivered in a more modular form so that, if they wish and depending on their age and their attitude, persons can add to their training for the whole of their working lives.

Training in this country is not sufficiently integrated. If people move across an industry or within an industry, there should be a logical career path for them to follow. Training is not properly accredited in many industries-a theme I will come to a little later. The quality of trainers in many areas is very poor. Overall, training should be linked to satisfactory career paths for individuals and also to wages and skill levels.

I mentioned earlier the problem of private providers of training. Recently electors have drawn my attention to a number of problems. Those problems concern the quality of training offered by private providers. In my State of Tasmania-and I am sure in many other areas of Australia-there are many private courses being promoted by various organisations. Two within the hospitality industry have been drawn to my attention. The providers of these private training courses talk about giving diploma and certificate courses. They advertise the places at which these courses are taught, such as Wrest Point. They give government registration numbers and talk in fairly glowing terms about the future for people who undertake these courses.

The two particular courses I am talking about were drawn to my attention by a number of electors. On checking into these hospitality training courses, I found that neither had any formal registration and that the providers had sought registration but had been rejected. The Government registration number in the advertisement was not a registration number of the training course but the membership number of their employer association. The private providers claimed to give diplomas and certificates. That is totally misleading. If those courses are not accredited, the title `Diploma' or `Certificate' means absolutely nothing. The content of the courses on evaluation is not in accord with recently established national standards in the hospitality industry.

Heavy promotion is given to the venue. People who read the advertisements in the case of Wrest Point, which I have mentioned, will see that it seems to indicate that Wrest Point is delivering the course. On checking, the general manager of that establishment found to his horror that his establishment had been booked by this training company not on the basis that training courses were to be provided but on the basis that the training company was having a function there.

Individuals pay quite a deal of money for the privilege of attending these courses. In this case, the individual who came to me had to pay $200 and, on attending the course, was asked to pay further money for materials. When the examination was conducted at the end of the course, the training providers and the supervisors left the room. So everyone cheated and everyone got an A plus. Having completed this examination in which everyone obtained an A plus, the participants were urged to go into the work force and work for nothing to gain experience-in fact, urging individuals to breach the industrial law. I suppose to add insult to injury from the point of view of being a Tasmanian, on investigating and making my phone calls, which were quite difficult to make, I found the courses are based in Sydney.

It is that area of private providers of training in which there is very little regulation or control. It is an area that I believe needs a great deal of research and one which I have referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which I am a member.

The challenge that this country faces, particularly in the economic sphere, is a very difficult one. The future economy of the world in the 1990s and well into the next century will be dominated by the Asia-Pacific region, of which we are a part. It will also be dominated by the north Atlantic countries as a co-dominion. We are part of the international economic system; there is no way of avoiding that. The challenge for the Labor Party will be to ensure that we can successfully compete against that economic system. The challenge for the Labor Party will be to ensure that for the people of Australia this is carried out in terms of our social justice and equity goals. The challenge for me as a senator for Tasmania will be to ensure that those goals are carried out. That is a challenge that I intend to meet.
