DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Drugs, Crime and Society. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief remarks on one aspect of the Government's response put down by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). The Government has had this report before it for some time-since June last year-but not for quite as long as governments sometimes have reports before them. I welcome this response.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to direct my remarks particularly to page 7 of the response in which the Government addresses the recommendation that the Commonwealth prohibit tobacco advertising to the full extent that it has the power to do so. The response then points out that the Commonwealth prohibited tobacco advertising in the electronic media as long ago as 1976. We have been informed that further Commonwealth action has taken place following the passage through this place and the House of Representatives in December last year of an Australian Democrats private member's Bill to implement a total ban on tobacco advertising in all print media.

The Government in its response reiterates the point made then, that it believes that tobacco advertising on billboards, hoardings and in cinemas is a matter for State and Territory governments. Some governments have acted in this area. I think it is worth noting that in this area it appears at this point that the New South Wales Government is taking the longest time to come to the view which has been reached by South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia by way of legislation and by Tasmania, Queensland, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory by way of draft legislation. We await developments in New South Wales.

The remaining area of Federal responsibility contained in the Government's response relates to elements of the Broadcasting Act which allow for what is known as `incidental tobacco advertising'. That exemption to the electronic advertising ban, which was in the legislation in 1976, has resulted in the broadcast of events such as the Benson and Hedges World Series Cricket, Winfield Cup Rugby League and so on. In fact, there has been an injection of an enormous amount of tobacco industry money into sports sponsorship via which electronic advertising has continued, particularly on television.

The Government has stated in its response that it believes that any proposal to remove this exemption needs to be evaluated and the likely impact on such sponsorships has to be looked at, as does alternative sources of funding for these activities. We are told that the Government intends to examine this matter and that a further statement will be made at a later time.

The Australian Democrats have looked at this matter. At this point I will not take the time of the Senate to put our point of view. I simply say that, as foreshadowed last year and again earlier this year, in the next few weeks we will be moving amendments to the broadcasting legislation to close that loophole and to address the concern which remains in the area of advertising tobacco products and which is leading to an increase in the use of tobacco products. This is a major public health issue in this country. Because this is an area of responsibility of the Commonwealth, we believe that, as the last move in the area of electronic media took place in 1976, it is certainly high time the Commonwealth played the role that it should play in terms of closing the loophole which was left there.

On the question of alternative sources of funding, the Commonwealth Government does not have to look very far. In those States where the State responsibility has been taken up, organisations have been established to provide alternative funding of a very satisfactory nature. An example of this is the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation in my own State. As the Australian Grand Prix just yesterday would have shown, it is not absolutely essential that the tobacco companies have everything their own way. Of course, a minor exemption was made by the State Government of Victoria in that case. Nevertheless, the major sponsor did turn out to be a health promotion sponsor rather than a tobacco sponsor.

I look forward to the Government's further statement on this matter. I simply hope that the statement will be available at the time the Democrats put forward their amendments to the broadcasting legislation in order to close the loophole which, as this report notes, is clearly a concern of the Government. We will then have carried out the recommendation of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority that the Commonwealth act in all ways it can against the advertising of tobacco products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise just to make a few very brief remarks, particularly in view of the fact that we will have before us, possibly late tonight or tomorrow, the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill 1990 which seeks to extend certain powers in relation to detention of and search for people who may be carrying so-called hard drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to page 3 of the Government's response which reviews the findings of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. It states:
The Committee held that, contrary to popular belief, the majority of users of drugs of dependence do not become addicted to them, and addicts generally give up their drug use sooner or later.

I stress that of all the drug-related deaths that occur in Australia, some 80 per cent are related to the consumption of tobacco in one form or another; some 10 per cent are related to the consumption of alcohol; and all other drugs together make up the other 10 per cent, of which hard drugs-the figures which I have are now several years old-make up only 2 or 3 per cent. Yet enormous efforts, enormous amounts of funds and so on go into the prevention of death and injury in respect of that very small percentage.
It is interesting, therefore, that the Committee has found and the Government has chosen to reiterate the Committee's finding, that:
. . . contrary to popular belief, the majority of users of drugs of dependence-

That certainly puts the onus fairly and squarely on to the Government not to procrastinate too long in referring this report to the ministerial committee and waiting for yet another report before some action is taken. It is quite clear to me at least that we need to change our policy in relation to the treatment of those who use the so-called drugs of addiction and who, if handled in an appropriate way, can be got through to the stage where they will very often spontaneously give up those--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the traffickers-not the victims? What is your social policy on that?

—As I suggested in a motion in the Senate, I think two years ago, if we were to make those drugs available to consumers of the drugs under conditions of medical safety and legal safety, we might well overcome the problem of the traffickers by undercutting the market and removing the enormous crime associated with that trafficking, which quite clearly involves this country in enormous expense. SPEECH.PARA: I simply stress the figures again. I stress that we are putting enormous resources into a very small part of the overall problem if what we are concerned about is the damage to health and the damage to life which the consumption of drugs causes. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory election and electoral system. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am most concerned about the response the Government has given us regarding the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I believe that it replaces parliamentary representative democracy with Cabinet authoritarianism. In accepting recommendations 1 to 6 in the report, the Government has made mechanical alterations which could be applied regardless of the system of voting that was being used.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 7 in this report is the key recommendation. It offers the chance to meet those very concerns which led to the generation of the report. In paragraph 4 of the Government's response we are told:

. . . the D'Hondt system was introduced into the House by the Government . . . following clear indications by the Opposition parties that they would not support the introduction of either a single member constituency system, or a system under which half the members are elected using House of Representatives rules and half using Senate rules.

The Government rightly believes that support for those options would not be given now either. But that does not mean that the D'Hondt system remains the only possibility. The recommendations in the report clearly cite the proportional representation system used in Tasmania. Why would the Government support this recommendation in the Committee, yet reject it in the response that we have before us now? We have in the response the feeble line, `in view of the costs associated with conducting a referendum . . .' I cannot accept that.

Are we now so parsimonious that we count the costs of democracy? While we are spending millions of dollars per week parading about on foreign seas defending America's oil interests, here in our symbolic seat of democracy we quibble at spending a few hundred thousand dollars to exercise one of the basic tools of democracy-the referendum. I ask whether this is the best response the Government can come up with:
. . . in view of the costs associated with conducting a referendum, the Government has decided not to accept the Committee's Recommendations 7, 8 and 9.

Does this pathetic response truly reflect this Government's valuation of democracy? I hope that in this chamber the Opposition will reject such an attempt to ignore, even to insult, its members on that Committee. I hope that members of the Opposition, as champions of the rights of the individual, will not be misled by the backroom boffins, the manipulating mandarins, who place such a low value on the due processes of democracy. On page 77 of the report we see the following statement:

The Australian Electoral Commission pointed out that the extraordinary length of the ballot paper, a factor which contributed to the duration of the count, was not caused by the number of candidates, but by the number of parties, and by the requirement that independent candidates be listed horizontally above the ballot line.

It is the contention of the Australian Democrats that the D'Hondt system is an abomination-that in fact it is not an electoral system but a list system which favours party listing. That is evidenced by the ACT Administration information pamphlet, which in part reads:
Under the D'Hondt system in Europe, voters normally only mark the ballot paper once to indicate the party of their choice.

That appears on page 65 of the report. It is the D'Hondt system which has encouraged the creation in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) of a multitude of parties which tried to distinguish themselves from each other by composing their extraordinary names. I am sure that we are all too well aware of those. Those very names and those very parties were not created in response to a particular community desire to generate political parties but were imposed as a result of the system, the abomination, which we ended up with.

To resolve that problem, if the Joint Standing Committee's recommendations were accepted in full, we would have the opportunity to establish in the Australian Capital Territory an electoral system which would give ACT electors the opportunity to democratically choose a system which would not suffer the anomalies and the problems of the D'Hondt arrangement and which might actually reflect the preference of the electors. I recommend the Committee's recommendations in full.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE AND THE COMMUNITY: A PARTNERSHIP IN AUSTRALIA'S DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is a most important document in the debate on the defence of Australia. It is a challenging document. It is not one with which everybody will agree and certainly there are many things in it with which I do not agree. Nevertheless, it is a very important step along the way to raising the awareness of defence as an issue in this country, which is long overdue, and it has to make for debate on defence in this country to be better informed.

In his report, Mr Wrigley has proposed a number of measures. It is a very large report, approximately two inches thick, and certainly deserves substantial study by anybody concerned with defence in this country. There is not a lot of time today to discuss the report in depth, but in it Mr Wrigley canvasses issues such as the civilianisation of the Defence Force and the privatisation of some of the functions, both of which are measures which other defence forces, notably those of the United Kingdom, where I visited last year, have taken steps towards. Some of those steps can be very useful, but-and I issue a note of caution here-they are sometimes not appropriate and we could find, when the time came to defend the country, that some of these measures did not allow us the flexibility we should have.

One of the issues that concerned me about Mr Wrigley's report is that he compared Australia's situation with those of several countries with which I do not believe there is a fair comparison, namely, countries in Europe where conscription is part of life and where people then go on to national service, a continuing reserve obligation. That does not occur in Australia. Mr Wrigley also compares Australia with the United States of America, where there are enormous financial attractions for putting people into the reserve forces. That does not happen in this country and it is not proposed here because of the enormous expenditure. If it is, it is not costed.

I am concerned that Mr Wrigley proposes that we no longer have any need for an expeditionary-type force. One only has to recognise the vast size of this country to realise that we must be able to take our operational deployment force to the far corners of the country with the logistic support that it would need. When I have spoken to Mr Wrigley on this matter he has said that civilians will be there and that when Australia is attacked they will bring up the arms and ammunition.

I am concerned because the history of the union movement in Australia has not been one that would give us reason to believe that the support would be there when the country needed it. We have had several occasions when ships going to war have not been loaded when the need arose. Even Kangaroo 89, the exercise last year, had to be rewritten to some extent because some ships were tied up at the dock because of a dispute.

Mr Wrigley would like us to recruit 52,000 men and women for a reserve force, and yet only last week the Auditor-General reported on how, in his assessment, the reserves have become ineffective through lack of training and resources; he doubted that Australia would be able to recruit even 26,000-half the number proposed by Mr Wrigley-by the end of this century. I understand that Mr Wrigley relied quite heavily on the material unearthed by the Auditor-General, and I find it strange that he did not come to that conclusion himself.

We have to remember that over the last six or seven years the regular force and the reserve force have both gradually become more and more under-resourced and their manpower levels are getting lower and lower. So anybody who is concerned with our defence forces and with the defence of Australia should take these two reports and study them closely. They are both extremely valuable in the national debate and should not be ignored by serious commentators who want to see our country better defended.

The Government needs to be indicted because of some of the results that have been documented for us by the Auditor-General. I must congratulate his staff on the way they dealt with the difficulties of coming to grips with some of the material which was not readily available. We have a reserve force which is demonstrably not as effective as it should be and yet we are training those people at a relatively high cost compared with the regulars; they also are not getting the support they need.

Taken together, the Wrigley report and the Auditor-General's report into the Department of Defence, Australia's Army Reserve, are two major statements which this Government must address. The debate on defence must not be allowed to die. It is the most important issue that faces this country.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This document has just been received by honourable senators. It covers a wide range of matters affecting the disabled community. It is an extremely important document and I believe it will arouse some fears within the disabled community. Today I wish to speak to only two items in this report which are the concern of the veterans community, namely, the National Acoustics Laboratory (NAL) and the Rehabilitation and Artificial Limb Appliance Centre (RALAC). The National Acoustics Laboratory has been studied in considerable detail. There was an interim report brought down a month or so ago by the Industry Commission. As a result of that report evidence was taken around the country and this final report has now been produced.

The National Acoustics Laboratory has a number of recommendations, the most important of which is that it be permitted to compete with other suppliers for non-hearing services programmed clients provided it is first converted to a government business enterprise operating on a fully commercial basis.

One of the most outstanding features of the National Acoustics Laboratory, for anybody who has any dealings with it, is the incredible and inordinate delays for people awaiting a hearing test. The report gives examples: the actual waiting time at Hurstville in New South Wales had risen from 20 weeks in August 1989 to 37 weeks in January 1990, while, for the same period, actual waiting time at Orange had risen from nine weeks to 22 weeks. In a number of NAL hearing centres, it was reported, the waiting time as at 29 May 1990 was as high as nine months. The Commission came to the conclusion that even the reduced waiting times which NAL is now achieving are not satisfactory and that greater competition in the private market will be in the interests of all concerned If that will bring down the waiting time I believe veterans, amongst other disabled people, will find that a great improvement.

It seems quite strange, when we turn to the RALACs, that the Commission did not make a similar recommendation. In fact, it suggested that the RALACs should be abolished. In the interim report the possibility was canvassed that they remain under public ownership, but the final report suggested that the RALACs should be abolished. I feel that would be a severe distortion of the system at this stage. In my own mind there did not appear to be a sufficient number of private enterprise organisations to be able to cope with the number of disabled people who need limbs. Down the track, that probably would be the case. A better proposition would be to have two stages whereby there would be much greater competition, and a freeing-up and deregulation of the system-which is currently very heavily regulated by the Government, through the Department of Veterans' Affairs-and once the private sector had taken up the slack, possibly the RALACs could be shut down if it was still considered necessary.

Amongst a number of quite useful recommendations there seems to be one quite clearly not covered that I would have expected to be there. There seems to be no requirement for prosthetists to be accredited. It seems to me that as paramedics are in similar positions to physiotherapists and the like, it is an important omission. The issues facing the industry are training and supervision of standards, and accreditation of the prosthetists, I would have thought, was an absolutely vital ingredient if we are to go down the route that the Industries Commission is suggesting in this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

In speaking to the annual report of the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC), I would like to comment on several matters which should be of grave concern to all honourable senators. During the recent Estimates Committee the AEC assured the Committee that the goal of maintaining an accurate, complete and continuous electoral roll was to be discharged by undertaking comprehensive habitation reviews across the entire nation. This step should help to ensure that elections are held using the cleanest possible electoral rolls.

In a debate in May this year many senators aired concerns about the state of the rolls, and cited many problems and irregularities that have been drawn to their attention. The major problem is that none of us have the capacity to undertake the detailed examination necessary to check allegations of this nature, so any complaints are usually dismissed as purely anecdotal.

We await with interest the results of the AEC survey investigating enrolments in six electorates in the lead-up to the last election, and we expect an undertaking that resources will be made available to correct any weaknesses identified in Commission records and procedures.

In this context it is rather alarming to note that the submission of the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party to the Electoral and Administrative Review Commission warns of considerable pressure upon the AEC to achieve financial savings. We seek assurances from the Government that any economies will not be at the expense of improving the State rolls.

Another concern I have is that should our State of Queensland decide to introduce a joint enrolment system, with the Commonwealth undertaking the responsibility for maintaining the rolls, then Queensland will again suffer because resources are not made available to cope with the State's population boom. We are all familiar with the unfairness shown in allocating, for example, funds for education, which has seen the supply of tertiary places in Queensland lag far behind the level warranted by equity and population pressure. The problem will be particularly acute given that Queensland growth rates show no sign of abating.

Before surrendering its right to maintain an interest in this process the State Government would be well advised to ensure that Queenslanders do not suffer yet again because of the distorted priorities of this Federal Government.

In Estimates we were told the Commonwealth expected to realise significant savings if the joint enrolment procedures were introduced. What are the odds of any of this money being spent in Queensland to upgrade the rolls?

I point out that the largest electorates in the whole of Australia are McPherson and Fisher in Queensland, and that the top five electorates across all States are in Queensland. The AEC states its goal is to keep divisional enrolments as equal as possible over the life of a redistribution, but the dynamic population growth in my State of Queensland has made this an impossible dream.

The difficulties were heightened by significant flaws in the projections of enrolment increases relied upon by the AEC in preparing the Queensland redistribution. Unfortunately, the AEC allowed local divisional returning officers to adjust projections based on their so-called local knowledge. There were some spectacular errors. The worst was in McPherson-which is based on the Gold Coast-which ended up at the redistribution mid-point in December 1987 as more than 14 per cent over the target. Because of its strategic position on the State border this led to a ripple effect which caused many seats to vary significantly from the average enrolment. In fact, of Queensland's 24 seats, fully eight were more than 5 per cent off target at the half-way point, compared with the statutory goal of no more than 2 per cent variance.

We are concerned to ensure that the redistribution due next year does not suffer from the same handicap, and have sought an undertaking that the enrolment projections research paper is released well in advance of the deadline for submission so that it can be carefully examined and, if necessary, the projections for underlying assumptions can be challenged.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I wish briefly to draw to the attention of the Senate the problems being faced by the Australian Maritime College (AMC), which is an excellent organisation and has been the centre of excellence for the nation in training maritime students. It has had enormous difficulty over seven months in trying to get some sort of response from the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) to the amalgamation safeguards which the college proposed back in February of last year. For seven months the college has waited for a reaction from that Department.

The college gave general approval of the broad principles of amalgamation in September 1989. It is keen to retain its role as the national centre for maritime education and training and it has tried, therefore, to maintain its identity as a college within the new university which is to be put together with the maritime college, the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology and the University of Tasmania.

The Federal Government's delay in responding to the maritime college I find quite incomprehensible, rude and certainly not in the best interests of the students who will be attending the maritime college in the future.

The maritime college wishes to maintain a nexus with the Commonwealth, although it is prepared to see a new single, integrated university in Tasmania. I draw the attention of the Senate to the quite unacceptable delays occasioned by DEET to an organisation which deserves prompt and courteous attention, and a response to reasonable requirements in what was supposed to be a negotiated position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Maritime College has gone through the development stages and is now at one of consolidation. The college's first students were enrolled in 1980 and, since that time, it has developed into an institute which has been recognised as one of the leading maritime education and training institutions. This has enabled Australia to ratify an international convention on the standards of training and certification for seafarers and to implement current Government initiated changes to shipboard practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the college is being encouraged to take on more students, it has not received a funding boost in the 1989-91 triennium. Thus the course offerings unfortunately have had to be reappraised. Because of the demands placed upon the college to serve the training needs arising from the adoption by the Commonwealth of recommendations of the Shipping Reform Task Force a budget shortfall of $324,724 was expected in 1989 and whilst reimbursement of this deficit has been promised by the Commonwealth, as of September 1990 unfortunately no money has been received. So unless additional funding is provided for the college it will not be in a position to provide the sum total of training required as per the recommendations of the Shipping Reform Task Force for the remainder of the triennium.

The second matter I wish to address is the proposed amalgamation of the Australian Maritime College (AMC) with the University of Tasmania and the Tasmanian Institute of Technology. Following some eight months of negotiations, the AMC's council endorsed in September 1989 the principle outlined in the heads of agreement negotiated between the three parties relative to a merger of the three institutions. So the move towards amalgamation had resulted from policy initiatives embodied in the Commonwealth Government's July 1988 White Paper and, although it is a viable institution in its own right, the AMC did not qualify for membership of the unified national system and was consequently left with no option but to seek an amalgamation partner.

The AMC will enter amalgamation mindful of the national nature of the college and the need to be able to protect its role within the combined state tertiary body. One of the college's success stories is its consultancy and research company, AMC Search Ltd, which undertook 52 projects during 1989. The largest project was a half a million dollar contract with Petrona's Malaysian national oil company, which involved the ship sim-modelling of the design of the maritime marine facility for a refinery in Malaysia and a simulation study to determine the optimum layout and the design of the facility. Computer models of oil spills and fire and explosion scenarios were produced, as were guidelines for procedures in the event of emergencies.

Other policies included an intensive training program packaged and presented for crew members of the Australian first liquefied natural gas (LNG) ship, the North West Sanderling, and a deep water fisheries course for the crew of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation new research vessel, the Aurora Australis.

In 1989 the demand from overseas for the college courses once again proved strong, mainly from students who wished to pursue courses of study to prepare them as candidates for marine certificates of competency. Because of its close relationship with the United Nations international maritime organisations and its links with other maritime institutions and because of the quality of its teaching and facilities, the AMC is becoming increasingly identified as the premier centre for marine education and training in the Asian-Pacific region.
The Commonwealth Government needs to give serious consideration to the funding requirements of the AMC in order for it to retain its reputation as a premier education and training centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the report of the Committee entitled `Construction of the Perth Office and Warehouse Complex for the Civil Aviation Authority'. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Committee has concluded that there is a need for the construction of a Perth office and warehouse complex for the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The proposed office building will have an area of 5,508 square metres on two levels, and the area of the warehouse is proposed to be 1,120 square metres. The cost of $13.926m will be reduced by the sale of the CAA's warehouse site at Mount Claremont in Perth.

The Committee heard evidence that the Western Australian field office of the CAA is presently located in expensive leased accommodation in Perth's central business district. The lease on this property expires in October 1991. The CAA accepted the report of the consultant who recommended the move from the leased accommodation to Perth Airport because: leasing costs are high; the CAA's major clients are at Perth Airport; and savings could be made by way of relocating the office staff. The CAA purchased a suitable block by the Perth Airport in November 1988. The Committee supports the CAA's belief that it should be in a decentralised location, close to its clients.

There are a few brief points I would like to make in connection with this report. First, the roof of the warehouse at Mount Claremont contained asbestos sheeting. Evidence was given that this is safe provided it is undisturbed. Should a new owner decide to demolish the building, care will need to be taken to adhere to the appropriate Western Australian code of practice for the removal of this material.

Secondly, the Committee was told that use of solar panels for heating within the proposed building was not found to be practical commercially. The Committee reiterates the point made during last week's tabling of the report into the Australian Taxation Office's dedicated computer centre that means of improving energy efficiency in new buildings will be kept under scrutiny.

Thirdly, the CAA's original proposal had included sale of its workshops at Mount Lawley. The combination of a National Trust classification on the main building, restrictions on construction on the block and uncertainty about the future of the CAA's workshops combined to remove this from the proposal. The Committee accepts this situation and, while not making a recommendation on the issue, endorses the principle of bringing all relevant CAA operations to Perth Airport.

Finally, there were concerns expressed about such things as public transport to the airport, banking and child care facilities and the cost and availability of food in that part of the airport.
