TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on this legislation towards the end of last week, Senator Cooney, speaking for the Government, claimed that the Opposition's attitude to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 was determined, at least in part, by what he described as our unease with regard to trades unions and the ordinary working person. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, what we see today is the unease of the ordinary working person with trades unions.

SPEECH.PARA: In the private sector of the Australian economy less than one-third of employees today actually belong to trade unions. Workers are voting with their feet in terms of their attitude to trade unions and are showing a distinctly negative attitude to union organisations. There has been a significant decline in membership over a number of years.

A clear motive behind this legislation is an attempt to stem that decline in union membership by making preference to unionists much more stringent and thereby tightening up the de facto compulsion to belong to a trade union. People will have to join unions because of legislation-not because of the merits of union membership or because of the services or benefits that they might obtain by belonging to a trade union.

Why do we need such compulsion? Clearly, it is needed because all the other elements of this legislation reinforce the negative aspects of trade unionism which deter people from becoming members. I refer to the concentration and centralisation of power in few hands, the trampling on the rights of individuals, and the reinforcement of anti-democratic procedures. Each of these three negative elements is clearly evident when one considers the key purposes of this Bill and the specific clauses which give effect to them.

There are six key purposes to this legislation. The first is to increase the membership threshold. The minimum membership for which a trade union will qualify for registration will go from 1,000 members currently to 20,000. Secondly, it will make amalgamation procedures less stringent. Thirdly, the legislation will oblige the Industrial Relations Commission to take advice from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Fourthly, the Bill will recognise federations of unions prior to formal amalgamation. Fifthly, the Bill will provide exemptions from secret postal ballots. Sixthly, it will reinforce and extend preferences which the Industrial Relations Commission may extend to members of a trade union.

To give effect to those key purposes there are six focal clauses in this legislation. Clause 4 amends the objects of the existing Industrial Relations Act to encourage and facilitate the amalgamation and development of unions. Clause 10 amends section 118 of the Act to strengthen the onus of consultation on the Commission to consult peak organisations, such as the ACTU, when considering demarcation disputes arising from a union's attempt to extend its coverage. It obliges the Commission to consider not only agreements but also any so-called understanding.

Clause 11 reinforces the preference provisions of the Act and extends their scope. Clause 12 amends the minimum membership requirement for registration of a trade union from 1,000 to 20,000 members. Clause 14 proposes a two-stage review of the registration of small organisations-those with fewer than 1,000 members in the first stage and fewer than 20,000 members in the second stage-beginning in March 1992, to see whether they should continue to exist.

The final focal clause to which I refer is clause 15 which repeals the existing amalgamation provisions and replaces them with provisions which, firstly, explicitly recognise union federations under section 236; and, secondly, introduce a new section 253h, which provides an exemption from the necessity of having a secret postal ballot of members to approve amalgamation-a secret ballot of duly constituted meetings of members can suffice.

The plans by Mr Kelty-the somewhat controversial plans which he has had for some time-to reduce the number of unions connects with the ACTU's wages push outside the Industrial Relations Commission. This has its origins in the Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement document of May 1987 and in the Australia Reconstructed document of the same year. His plans and this legislation are recipes for further increasing and entrenching union power-not for improving industrial relations and productivity but, as I said earlier, for establishing a minimum size for Australian trade unions of 20,000 members. This is an increase of some 2,000 per cent in the minimum allowed size of trade unions. This will not be more conducive to the development and maintenance of effective industrial relations processes in any industry.

Labor's rationale that larger and fewer unions will achieve better industrial relations is fatally flawed. Kelty argues that the law has prevented unions rationalising federally. But these amendments will not allow a rational trade union structure to develop. There are currently about 300 or so registered trade unions and Kelty wants this number reduced to 20 mega-unions-a cut of some 93 per cent. Presently only 45 unions have memberships of more than 20,000. It will be interesting to observe the negotiations between union officials and their clamouring for this Government's amalgamation handouts at taxpayers' expense so that Kelty's cluster approach can be achieved.

The date specified after which newly registering unions will be required to have the larger membership is 28 February, 1990. All registered small unions would have a further two years, after which, if they failed to have 20,000 members, they would have to show cause why they should be allowed to stay registered. Why should the onus of proof be on a small union to justify its continued existence and survival?

Through this legislation the Hawke Labor Government is just caving in to Kelty and the ACTU and their fantasy of amalgamation for the union movement. That amalgamation agenda of the ACTU includes mergers flowing from the vote of only the smaller union body if it is less than 25 per cent of the body it is joining. It also seeks to allow the merging unions to form a federation which is recognised by law and can act on their behalf before industrial tribunals while the merger itself is being put in place.

This item has the effect of making the formal merger a fait accompli and more difficult to prevent by allowing the establishment of those federations. Allowing a vote in favour of a merger to be taken at a meeting of members, instead of by what the ACTU regards as the time-consuming and counter-productive method of the postal ballot, is just another part of their agenda. Of course, this is a much less democratic means of achieving mergers and amalgamations, because we all know of the thuggery that occurs at some union meetings in regard to votes taken on issues.

Also on the agenda is the freeing up of union funds and resources to promote the cause of the merger. But what of funds for those wishing to oppose such a merger? There is no provision for that at all. There is also to be an allowance for unions to change their operating rules while a merger is under way. No doubt we will have to watch for some sleight of hand that will undoubtedly occur there.

Mr Kelty has suffered some embarrassing setbacks in the prosecution of his agenda-namely, the failure of hoped-for mergers between the building workers and the engine drivers and between the electricians and the engineers. His proposals require massive changes to the heartland of unionism in this country. We need to recognise that, contrary to what this legislation will provide, size on its own is no guarantee of internal efficiency of any union. It would be nothing more than national suicide to encourage and create an umbrella of cumbersome conglomerates which could fall into the control of a small group and particularly of the militant Left.

The coalition-the Liberal and National parties-firmly and wholeheartedly supports union restructuring, but we support it on the basis of the development of enterprise unions and enterprise agreements. This is a fundamental tenet of our industrial relations policy. It is clear that Kelty and the ACTU are stooping to desperate measures to shore up a dwindling union membership and their own power base. This legislation is nothing more than an attempt by Kelty and his ACTU colleagues to halt the decline of union membership and influence.

The requirement of a minimum union membership of 1,000-never mind 20,000-clearly violates the fundamental principle of freedom of association. It is a direct contravention of Convention No. 87 of the International Labour Organisation, to which Australia is a signatory, which established the right of workers to absolute freedom of association.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's wrong. What you have just said is wrong.

—It is not wrong, Minister. Even this Labor Government, or at least its more moderate factions, has had to recognise the need for deregulation and increased competition in business and government instrumentalities. We see the ongoing debate--
—It is wrong.
—Am I am wrong about the ongoing debate on Telecom Australia and Australian Airlines, Minister?
—You are wrong about that assumption.

—The Government, quite contrary to its initiatives in those other areas, is putting up legislation which will tighten the anti-competitive, monopolistic stranglehold of the unions. On the one hand Minister Beazley and Treasurer Keating are fighting publicly over the limits of increased competition that they think their Party members might tolerate in telecommunications and, on the other, the Government has introduced a Bill, which is before us, seeking to decrease competition.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that in this area, and indeed with the development of its megacom proposals, the Government endorses the concept that big is beautiful. It seems to have forgotten that big is also unwieldy and unresponsive to individual needs and requirements and, by definition, concentrates power into the hands of a few. Mega-unions that do not have to compete for membership will have no necessity to bend over backwards to look after their members. Amalgamation of unions into 20 or so mega-unions will not lessen demarcation disputes. The only way to do that is through enterprise-based unions, and the minimum size requirements of this legislation will actively prevent such organisations from coming into existence.

Kelty's big dream has a number of very serious defects and detrimental consequences for Australia-that is, if it is ever realised. It would prevent forever the emergence of enterprise unions. No empirical evidence exists to support fewer but larger unions as being more efficient, or for that matter any more conciliatory, than that which currently exists. We need only look at the behaviour of the building industry unions and the metal unions over the years to confirm that.

A study by the Business Council of Australia called Enterprise-Based Bargaining Units: A Better Way of Working, which the Opposition applauds and supports, argues most comprehensively that there should be fewer unions within enterprises or industry. We support that view. The Council's survey highlighted that amalgamations of small unions, however, would not reduce the number of major unions among its member enterprises. It is those major unions which are responsible for most of the demarcation disputes which cripple industry from time to time. Fewer unions would not necessarily result in fewer disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you see the logical flaw in this argument?
—There is no logical flaw, Minister. The only way to overcome demarcation disputes is to have one union per enterprise. That is achieved by having enterprise unions.
—You don't see the logical flaw in your position at all then?

—There is no logical flaw in the coalition's position and that is clearly recognised in the community which has accepted our policy and strongly endorsed it over the last couple of years. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures has shown that minimum sizes seem more likely to reduce the number of federally registered industry-focused unions than they are to reduce the number of federally registered craft unions.

SPEECH.PARA: The union movement's amalgamation proposals, to which this legislation gives effect, will not solve the problem of multiple coverage in workplaces. As an example, the top 12 unions which have membership in Business Council workplaces will only be reduced to nine under the union amalgamation proposals. This will not significantly reduce the number of unions in most workplaces because the extent of overlapping membership is relatively small. Take for example the recent rubber workers-storemen and packers amalgamation. That amalgamation will reduce the number of unions in only 4 per cent of plants. A more significant amalgamation, such as the proposed Australian Workers Union-Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia amalgamation, will reduce the number of unions in just 16 per cent of plants.

So much more is needed than the approach endorsed and supported by the ACTU and which will be implemented if this legislation passes. Amalgamation needs to be linked to productivity, instead of the amalgamation and the development of unions as being an end in itself. There is no encouragement of new, single enterprise unions and, as I have said, if this Bill were successful in being passed, the emergence of new, single enterprise unions would be prevented.

The section 118 amendments will increase the ACTU's influence on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's deliberations of demarcation disputes which arise from union claims of coverage of workers by increasing the onus on the Commission to consult with the ACTU and by obliging the Commission to consider not only agreements but also undertakings. However, these so-called undertakings are not defined and the practical effect of these proposed changes will be to allow the ACTU to put a point of view as an undertaking in camera with no opportunity for any other party to confront it. The amendments significantly water down the important section 118 of the Act which allows the Industrial Relations Commission to alter union coverage by transferring members to another union and denying coverage by unions of particular industries.

The acknowledgment of federations of unions contained in the legislation is completely unnecessary because most unions would have such provision within the terms of their own constitutions. Practically speaking, its inclusion merely pre-empts the result of any subsequent vote on amalgamation by union members. Union members are not required to vote on federation, but acceptance of a proposal to federate by the Commission, with the commitment to amalgamate in three years time, will undoubtedly be represented by proponents of amalgamation as approval by the Commission for amalgamation. Therefore, the federation provisions effectively will reverse the onus of proof on opponents of amalgamation.

It will become easier for unions to control the vote by controlling membership of the meeting which is voting, with the introduction of a provision exempting amalgamation proposals from a secret postal ballot by members and the substitution of a secret ballot at duly constituted meetings of the members. As I said earlier, we know only too well how votes at many union meetings are conducted and the intimidation and thuggery that goes on at those meetings.
Clause 11, which reinforces and widens preference provisions, is a blatant attempt to make compulsory union membership universal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us an example of that allegation.
—There are plenty of examples, Minister. The clarification of clause 11 that preference be given to union members is--
—If you don't give us an example, there are none.
—I have had them drawn to my attention time and again by constituents since I have been a member of this Parliament.
—You are under privilege, name one.

—I will return again to clause 11. The clarification which clause 11 provides for preference to be given to union members in virtually every aspect of employment-hiring, promotion, regrading, training, leave and overtime-is aimed at ensuring that any person who is not a union member will be unemployable. It is a back-door way of forcing everyone to join a union if they want to work. It is a way of widening and legitimising the closed shop which is already widespread in many industries in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We have all seen the signs on building sites that read `No ticket, no start'. If the Government has its way with this legislation, we will see that sign up in every workplace in the land. It is a gross violation of civil liberties and a direct contravention of article 20, item 2 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which states: `No-one may be compelled to belong to an association.' How can this Government, which has sent its warships halfway round the world in the name of human rights and civil liberties, in the same breath try to bring in a piece of legislation that seeks to restrict those same rights for its own citizens?

Then we have the attitude of the Democrats to this legislation which was put last week by Senator McLean. In listening to his remarks last week, one could only be convinced that either Senator McLean has severe amnesia or else he must have been severely embarrassed at the speech he had to make because the Democrats that have joined him since the last election have caused an even greater lurch to the left on the part of that party. Senator McLean put the view that amalgamations of unions should be encouraged and accelerated. He indicated that his preferred minimum size and that of the Democrats was for 10,000 members, compared with the Government's proposed 20,000, but he really did not seem to be too fussed about whether it was one or the other.

I remind the Senate, and indeed the people of Australia, of what Senator McLean said on behalf of the Democrats in moving an amendment to the Industrial Relations Bill less than two years ago-an amendment which reduced the minimum union membership requirement from the Government's then proposal of 3,000 to just 1,000; an amendment which this Coalition supported in the absence of Democrat support for our own proposal for no minimum size. In moving for a minimum size of 1,000 Senator McLean said:

The Australian Democrats saw these amendments as constructive and responsible in that we have been approached by a considerable number of small unions who argue they are unable to find, and will remain unable to find even within the three-year period allowed for adjustment, compatible unions with which to amalgamate successfully. Some indicated they had in fact pursued the course of amalgamation in recent years only to find that it did not service their needs. They have withdrawn, only to find that this Bill proposes that they be forced into amalgamations which have proven unsuccessful.

We draw attention to the fact that our revised suggested figure of 1,000 as the minimum required limit of employer and employee organisations is simply in line with the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which proposed a minimum membership of 1,000 for both employer and employee organisations. This figure will provide an opportunity to meet the needs of smaller unions. This is the figure which the Government in the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill found acceptable and which at that time was acceptable to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).
We are not convinced that in the interim 15 months there has arisen a need for the Government or the ACTU to argue the non-acceptability of 1,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't accept it.

—Of course we do not accept it, because we do not believe that there should be any minimum size. But the Democrats less than two years ago said that 1,000 was the preferred minimum size for a trade union. We now see them falling into line with the Government and accepting at best a minimum size of 10 times what they were prepared to accept two years ago. We see Senator McLean supporting this massive increase from 1,000 to 10,000 in minimum size. These two minimum sizes are of a completely different order of magnitude and completely different logic in terms of preferred choice between them, and yet the Democrats have changed courses within the short space of two years. They have done so without so much as a `beg your pardon' or any justification or logical explanation in the speech which Senator McLean made to this chamber last week. One can only conclude that they have done yet another deal with the Government to get some preference with regard to some other activity further down the track.

SPEECH.PARA: Week by week it is becoming more evident that the Australian people have already decided who will be given the responsibility of governing this country after the next election-and we all know it will not be this mob opposite. What has been recognised is that this long-suffering country is sick of low productivity, and sick of the absence of wealth generation which this Government fails to encourage. Until our industries are free from the malaise affecting our transport system, our telecommunications sector and our over-regulated labour markets, productivity will remain the poor country cousin; and they will not be free from this malaise as long as Labor remains in office.

The accord, which this Government has trumpeted loudly over its time in office, is in fact part of the problem in Australia rather than being the solution. We must move away from a centralised wages system and place more focus on negotiations in the workplace together with enterprise-based bargaining structures and procedures if we are to determine wages and conditions fairly. The place of trade unions should not be as an arm of Executive Government, as they are under this Government, controlling industrial policies. Their place is not around the Cabinet table with de facto Cabinet member status directing decisions. Unions should represent their members in the workplace.

The so-called labour market is not really that at all in Australia. It is a centralised process whereby wages outcomes seemingly have no limit. We have wage increases which apply right across the board, disregarding the differing abilities of various industries and firms to pay these increases. Our nation's poor productivity is aggravated by this appalling labour system which has demonstrated its inability to accommodate changing industrial needs and the changed demands of international competition. Yet we still have some people living in cloud cuckoo land. Laurie Carmichael, ACTU Assistant Secretary and Deputy Chairman of the Australian Manufacturing Council, has actually stated:
. . . pressing industry to become more 'competitive alone' is not a policy pursued by other countries with whom we are required to compete.

Any casual observer would know the emphasis our competitors place on efficiency, making a complete nonsense of Carmichael's statement. But he is also ignoring the fact that our competitors are so far in front of Australia that they could rest on their laurels for some time before we would catch them, even if we make a serious commitment now to improve productivity. But of course, they will not wait for us; unless we act now, they will go further and further ahead.

We are ranked third, only behind Mexico and Brazil, as the most indebted nation in the world. Surely a more cooperative, a more flexible and a more effective industrial relations framework which reflects incentive and resourcefulness is what we desperately need-a system based on completely voluntary enterprise-based agreements as its primary feature, rather than the continuation of featherbedding. If we are going to solve our international debt problem, where the gap between imports and exports represents about 4 per cent of gross domestic product, we need in effect to increase output by 4 per cent from every worker and every business in a form that foreigners will buy or that we will buy instead of foreign products, without that being able to generate any improvement in our real living standards. That is the way we will have to operate if we are going to overcome that foreign debt problem.

The continuing approach of this Government, which is a broadly corporatist interventionist approach, will not provide the opportunity for that necessary increase in output. It is at the enterprise or workplace level where organisational and economic vitality originate and survive. Centralised productivity is but a statistic rather than a reality. Certainly there is an element of enterprise bargaining now under way in Australia, but this is just a move to catch up with longstanding arrangements overseas. Meanwhile, those overseas countries, as I said, are moving further ahead in their transformation to an even greater enterprise focus. That is why Australia must press forward to adopt the coalition's proposals for a complete enterprise-based industrial relations structure.

Contrary to what this Government believes, big is not beautiful; in fact, small is beautiful. Employee participation, decentralisation of organisation and power at all levels are ideas which have come of age in the Australian community. That is the best way of achieving productive outcomes in the labour market and, indeed, of encouraging cooperation between employers and employees to lift the productivity which this country desperately requires.

Instead of passing the amendments which this legislation seeks to achieve for the Industrial Relations Act, we ought to be amending the Act to enable a specified number of employees to apply to the Industrial Relations Commission for a change of union coverage in their workplace. We should also be amending the Act to permit the registration of new enterprise unions, totally regardless of size. That would allow us to move towards the approach which the coalition has for several years advocated as the only way to achieve meaningful improvement in our industrial relations structure. Our policy represents a complete break from centralised wage fixing and is the only alternative for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a sense of dismay and sadness that I note the introduction of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 into the Senate. For a long time, the Australian Labor Party, the people sitting opposite me, have purported to further the rights of the working class. Yet, by the introduction of this Bill and by its passage through this Parliament, the Labor Party will deprive ordinary workers of the right to self-determination; it will deprive ordinary workers of the chance to work harder for their betterment and for the betterment of their families; and it will take away the economic strength of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I shall address two matters. The first is the increasing preference for unionists which is included in this Bill and the second is the provisions in this Bill which relate to the forced amalgamation of unions, quite possibly against the wishes or the interests of the members of those organisations.

Let us first turn our attention to clause 11 of the Bill-the clause that extends the preference to unionists. I will tell honourable senators some of the matters to which that preference clause relates. It relates to the engagement in employment. That means that if one does not have a union ticket one does not get a job. It relates to promotion, regrading, transfer and retention in employment. In other words, if one ceases to be a unionist one can lose one's job. It relates to the taking of annual leave. In other words, if one does not pay union dues, one cannot go on holiday at Christmas if one wants to. It relates to overtime and it relates to vocational training. The message to the Australian worker and to the Australian public is very clear: unless workers abide by what union leaders tell them, in the future they will not have a chance in the work force; they will not have a chance to get on and provide for the future of their families.

Let us look in detail at some of the matters mentioned in clause 11. Let us look at retention in employment. What happens if workers cease to be union members? What happens if one does not join a union or belong to a union now and the provisions of this Bill take effect? It means that someone can determine whether a worker loses the right to keep the job. The right to a job and to promotion should be based solely on ability, and not the membership of a union.

We, on this side of the chamber, believe that people should have a right to work for their prosperity. Yet, in this Bill, we see pernicious attempts to take the incentive away from ordinary workers. We see an attempt by the other side of the House, the side that purports to govern in the national interest, to take away from people the opportunity to work harder and to improve their skills, and to take away the right to promotion on merit or to promotion based upon the contribution that employees make to the employers and to the Australian economy as a whole. That is why we and all thinking Australians believe that the provisions of this Bill are wholly unsatisfactory and that they constitute a backward step in civil rights.

I note with interest that when this Bill was introduced into this chamber last week, Senator Cooney, a well-known believer in civil rights and in the right of people to free association and so on, spoke in its favour. That disappointed me greatly. I would have thought that a man such as Senator Cooney, with his experience in these matters, would have recognised the dangers inherent in the passage of this Bill through the Parliament-the danger that once and for all ordinary workers, ordinary Australians, ordinary men and women with families and kids, will lose the right to security, to happiness and to prosperity because it is being taken away from them and put in the hands of their union bosses.

This argument is not raised on the basis of ideology or of vested interest-unless it is the vested interest of every single Australian worker, man or woman, to choose what organisation he or she will belong to, and to choose how, where and when he or she will work. This Bill will take that right away from them, and take it away for ever. That is why we, on this side of the chamber, are wholehearted in our opposition to this Government's attempts to destroy the rights of the working class.

Let us look at what this Government intends to do by way of forceful amalgamation of unions. It is very clear that this Government is wholeheartedly behind the idea of mega-unions. Why? Because it puts more power in the hands of the union leaders. When it puts more power in the hands of the union leaders, from whom does it take that power? It takes that power away from the ordinary worker in the shop, in the factory or on the work site. The workers are but a small cog in a large and inhumane machine; a small cog in an apparatus that can quite easily and happily ignore their wishes because they account for only a small number of members.

But that is wholly unsatisfactory for us and for the Australian population. We believe that people in this country should have a right-a fair dinkum, honest, inalienable right-to determine which organisation they will belong to and whom they will have representing their interests. The arguments that this Government brings forward with this Bill are analogous to saying, `Oh well, you can't belong to a political party unless it has a minimum number of members'. In essence, it says that ordinary Australians have lost the right to freedom of association and that they have lost the right to democracy in the workplace because they cannot determine who will represent them.

How will the big cudgel of the Labor Party be taken to the small defenceless unions? I will tell honourable senators how. It is written very clearly in this Bill. It will be taken in two stages. During stage one, between 1 March 1992 and 28 February 1993, organisations of employees fewer than 1,000 in number will be forced to justify their continued existence. During stage two, from 1 March 1994 to 28 February 1995, organisations of employees fewer than 20,000 in number will be asked to justify their continued existence. The mechanism by which this will be done will be to have a designated presidential member empowered to inquire into the continued existence of those organisations in what this Bill grandly calls `the public interest'.

What about the personal interests of the members of those organisations? What about the contribution that they have made over years, years and more years to the prosperity of their families? What about the contribution that they and their organisations have made to improving the standards in their workplace? That contribution will be lost once and for all. Their hard won freedoms-freedoms that those on the other side of the chamber spend so much time trumpeting about over and over again-will be lost forever. The Australian workers should ask themselves: Who is taking this freedom away from us? Who is taking away the rights that have been won? The sad answer is: the Labor Party which, for so many years, has masqueraded as the party that looks after the interests of Australian workers, but which is shown by this Bill and by the explanatory memorandum that supports this Bill to be the party that takes away the rights of the ordinary worker and the freedoms of ordinary Australians, and concentrates them in the hands of the faceless men in the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

As I have said, the intention of this Bill is that small organisations should have to justify their continued existence. It should be wrong that anybody in this country should have to justify his liberty, his freedom and his right of association. Those rights are inalienable rights recognised not just in this country and countries throughout the Western world but recognised by the international community at large, both in the United Nations charter and in other international conventions. These are inalienable rights and yet they seem to have been ignored by the Government in the introduction of this Bill. It brings me a grave sense of concern and a grave sense of sadness that government members can trample over the rights of ordinary Australians, with not even a sense of remorse or with an apology, but with a smile on their faces. I look over and I see Senator Bolkus grinning from ear to ear. I just think about the poor ordinary Australians who will lose out through the adoption of this Bill. It brings me a grave sense of concern that the Government should have so little respect for ordinary Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have been misrepresented by Senator O'Chee. The smile on my face was nothing to do with the issue at stake but with the fact that his speeches seem to be repetitive with the same type of emotion time and time again. We were just musing over the fact that Senator O'Chee is programmed for style, not substance.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Of course there is no point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Of course there is no substance to what Senator Bolkus said. It was merely a cynical attempt by Senator Bolkus to justify the behaviour of this Government, a cynical attempt to justify its lack of concern for the rights of ordinary Australians. It shows the same contempt for Standing Orders that this Government has shown for Australian workers. That is yet another vindication of what we on this side of the chamber have been saying all along through this debate that this Bill is wholly unsatisfactory for Australian workers, for the Australian economy and for the future of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return to the provisions of this Bill relating to the forced amalgamation of unions. We have to ask ourselves what will happen to the members of the organisations that this Government hopes, implicitly, through the provisions of this Bill, will be deregistered? What will happen to those people? To start with, unless they join one of the mega-unions-and we have to assume that they do not belong to a mega-union for one very good reason: they do not believe that a mega-union can represent their interests fairly and squarely-they cease to be a member of an organisation within the meaning of the Act. If they cease to be a member of an organisation, they lose the possible right to the preferences given to members of an organisation under clause 11. Therefore, if people belong to a union and that union is deregistered, they will lose the potential right to engagement in employment, promotion, regrading, transfer, retention in employment, taking of annual leave, overtime and vocational training.

This Bill will take those rights away from all Australians in small unions unless they back down and say, 'Yes, we give in; we will join your mega-union'. The reason that those people do not want to belong to a mega-union in the first place is that they recognise that, as small cogs in a very large machine, they have very little importance at all to the union leaders.

It concerns me that not even the national interest but the public interest is being used to justify the loss of the personal rights of Australians that are being guaranteed in many other countries through international charters. Yet this Bill floats through this chamber and through this Parliament with a lack of concern and without any fanfare on the part of the Government. I suppose that, if I were in the Government and introducing this Bill, I would not be heralding its introduction into this Parliament with any great fanfare either because it is very clear that there is not a lot of good news in it for many ordinary Australians.

Increasingly the consequence of this Bill, increasingly the consequence of the forced amalgamation of small unions into mega-unions, will be a continued decline in union membership. I predict that increasingly there will be a sense of dissatisfaction with those big unions amongst ordinary Australians. Their members will try to vote with their feet. But we have already seen that the provisions of clause 11 of this Bill will penalise them for doing so and penalise them most unfairly.

But what of the process by which the unions will amalgamate? What of the process by which the members of those unions will be asked to decide whether to agree to the amalgamation? One of the provisions of this Bill that Senator Chapman so astutely pointed out a few moments ago is that there is a provision to avoid a secret postal ballot. Let me draw the attention of the chamber to a number of other provisions relating to the process of amalgamation that alarm me greatly as a person who is interested in civil liberty, freedom and the right of association. I refer the chamber to the amended section 237(1) of the Bill, which will provide for an existing organisation to use its financial and other resources in support of the proposed principal amalgamation.

In other words, all the odds are stacked in favour of the mega-unions. All of the resources of the union will be available to the union leaders to put their case. What of the people in a union who do not agree? They might in fact be the majority. Do they have any access under this Bill to the resources of a union-their union-to fight the case for amalgamation? Do they have the right to draw on those resources and say, 'No, we don't want to become a member of a mega-union'? The answer is very clear: the answer is no. This Bill denies to them the right to use the resources of a union to oppose an amalgamation. All the odds are working in one way. All the odds are in favour of only one side of the case and not both. That brings me a sense of despair. That would not be inconsistent with other provisions of the proposed amendments to the Industrial Relations Bill. For example, proposed section 242(3) provides:
...that an outline in no more than 3,000 words must provide sufficient information on the scheme to enable members of the existing organisations to make informed decisions in relation to this scheme.

But there is no provision in that subsection for the information to be true and correct. People can be provided with information but, if it is not true information and if it is not correct information, they do not have a snowball's chance in hell of making a right decision. Yes, they will make a decision but not necessarily the right decision, nor will it necessarily be the decision in their best interests. There is no provision for truth or correctness in this Bill, just as there is no moral truth or correctness in what the Government wishes to do by the introduction of this Bill. That is why I believe the Senate must reject the motion for the second reading of the Bill.

In conclusion, we have seen a move by the Government to extend the preference provisions for unions and, therefore, deny rights to people who are not members of unions. We have seen how the Government will brutally force the amalgamation of small unions and take away from ordinary Australians the right to determine who will represent them in the workplace and the right to freedom of association. Gone forever with this Bill will be the right of Australians to have enterprise unions.

As a Queenslander I took great pride and satisfaction in participating in the formation of watershed industrial relations laws in this country under the previous Queensland Government. These laws were embraced wholeheartedly by numerous enterprises throughout our State, ranging from Metway Bank Ltd, to Power Brewing, to the South East Queensland Electricity Board workers. I am greatly dismayed to see the industrial relations laws of this country going backwards at a time when they should be going forwards to give people more freedom, more rights and more opportunity and, most importantly, to give ordinary workers a greater sense of satisfaction in their jobs. This is what is being lost through the introduction of this Bill.

It is very clear that the people who received voluntary employment agreements in Queensland-the people at Power Brewing, the people at Metway, the people in 25 organisations across my State-were very happy with the right to form their own union. But under this Bill they will not have that right at all because unless they make 20,000 in number they do not make the grade. That is unsatisfactory to me and I know it is unsatisfactory to many ordinary Australians.

As we go into the last years of this century and enter the first couple of years of the next century, we should be looking for industrial relations laws that really address the question of efficiency, that really address the question of the satisfaction of workers with their jobs and that really address the question of how secure and comfortable people feel with the representation that they have in the workplace. Yet, as I have said, we have seen this Bill being introduced into this Parliament-a Bill which will turn back the clock on individual freedom, a Bill which will turn back the clock on reform of the labour market, a Bill which will turn back the clock once and for all on the opportunities of ordinary Australians.

We on this side of the House have brought before this chamber overwhelming arguments as to why this Bill should be rejected. If it transpires that the Australian Democrats, combining with the Government to do some dirty, shady deal behind the backs of the Australian people, put this Bill through with amendments so that, instead of having 20,000 members a union has to have only 10,000, I hope and trust that the Australian people, the ordinary workers of this country, will remember who did the dirty deed to them. I hope that they will remember that this Government and the Democrats took away their right to freedom of association and took away their opportunity.

For those reasons we oppose this Bill; for those reasons the Australian population will oppose this law; and for those reasons I believe that this Bill is a gross contravention of the rights of ordinary Australian workers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we find the Government kowtowing to the unions. We have the spectacle of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) saying to Bill Kelty, `I will jump, but just how high do you want me to jump?'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has responded to the direction of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in a number of ways. The purpose of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 is to implement the ACTU's agenda. It does it in a number of ways: firstly, by reducing the number of trade unions from about 326, which we have in Australia at present, to about 20 industry-based unions; secondly, by strengthening the ACTU by forcing, through legislation, the Industrial Relations Commission to consider consulting with the ACTU and employer councils prior to exercising its powers in relation to demarcation disputes; thirdly, by strengthening the union preference provision; and, fourthly, by providing an exemption from secret postal ballots.

I will deal with these points one at a time. The first is the decision to increase the minimum membership of unions from 1,000 to 20,000. As I said, the aim is to end up with 20 industry unions. This obviously discourages the formulation of small enterprise-based unions-unions which can easily negotiate with their employer for better pay and conditions in return for greater productivity. These individual agreements would not flow on to other enterprises.

I will give one example. Honourable senators will remember how efficient individual negotiations can be. I would like to talk about Mudginberri. The 27 employees of Mr Pendarvis at an abattoir in the Northern Territory were delighted with his offer of better pay for greater productivity. They accepted these contract rates. Rather than being inhibited by the limit imposed by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) on the number of beasts they could kill in a day, he told them that if they killed more beasts than the unions allowed them to, he would pay them greater wages.

The immediate result of that employer-employee negotiation was that both parties were delighted. The men received more money and the employer had greater productivity. The employer had greater export markets and Australia benefited from those overseas markets.

However, that is where the happy story ended because then the AMIEU, backed by the Government and the ACTU, set up a picket line and stopped those enterprise agreements. Indeed, the Government's own inspector refused to cross the picket line and he was backed by the Minister of the day. Consequently, that enterprise lost its exports and even though it won a court case, the company finally went broke. Once again, Australia lost precious overseas markets-a situation very common with this Government. The Government was assisted in that by the ACTU.

The Government is so sure of the support of the Australian Democrats that it is treating this Senate with absolute disdain. The Minister does not believe that he should be here taking his own legislation. He passes the responsibility on to Senator Bolkus, of all people.

Apart from the creation of large militant unions under this Bill, the Commissioner would be forced by this legislation to consult with the ACTU. The legislation actually says, 'consider consulting' but the pressure on the Commission resulting from the inclusion of this clause is considerable. If, during consultation between the Commissioner and the ACTU, the unions assure the Commissioner that there will be an all-out strike if they do not get their way, what sort of pressure will that put on the Commissioner to change his opinion? The employers are meant to be consulted too, but they do not take strike action. The ACTU can put considerable pressure on the Commissioner. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this evening the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, which can be easily described as the Bill by which the Government seeks to ensure that, yes, there are fewer unions, but bigger unions-20,000 being the minimum membership of unions, with some minor exemptions. I want to speak against that proposal on the basis that the Government's emphasis is in the wrong direction.

SPEECH.PARA: I will paraphrase some words of a former Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. He made the remark that only 32 per cent of private sector employees in Australia belonged to unions. He thought that fact should be borne in mind by `those who believe that the sine qua non of better industrial relations is a tidier and more convenient institutional framework for the peak councils of unions and employers and the Federal Government'.

It is my view that that is what this Government believes-that a better industrial relations system is achieved by having a tidier and more convenient institutional framework for peak councils of unions, employers and the Federal Government. There is not much space in there for union members. It is not more convenient for them to be part of a union of 20,000 members.

It is no surprise to women, in particular, that unions have been losing favour in the community. Their membership proportionally is dropping. It is a matter of particular interest that in 1976 just under 44 per cent of women were in the labour force. Now, as we all know, the figure is up over 51 per cent.

It is interesting that the participation of women in that time-between 1976 and 1989-has soared, one might say. But when one looks at female union members as a proportion of the labour force, one finds that it was around 38 per cent in 1976 and has declined to about 36 per cent. While more women are rushing into the work force, they are not rushing into union membership, and that is because the unions have not been delivering. They have been so concerned with their own internal power plays, and doing things other than representing the best interests of the person on the shop floor, that the person on the shop floor has said, `Look, Jack, you can go somewhere else. I am not joining if I can possibly avoid it'.

It is a matter of regret to me that a large number of people cannot get a job unless they join a union. If it were the case that we had true voluntary association, one could choose whether one wanted to join or not and still get a job on a building site-for example, in Adelaide where as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, will know well, there are plenty of signs up saying, `No ticket, no job'. Unions cannot be proud of the membership they have at the moment. A good proportion of it they have only because people need to survive.

That is the first point I want to make: the Government has got it wrong. If the Government is hoping that streamlining union membership-shoving people into bigger unions-is going to be a good thing, I think it is mistaken. Yes, it will make it easier for the Government to negotiate with the peak employer groups and unions, and for those two groups to negotiate with the Government, but it has left out the little bloke-the employee-whom they are meant to be representing.

The Australian Labor Party now seems, in one respect at least, to have come round to the views that have been put by this Opposition for a long time. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may well remember that when the coalition's industrial relations policy was bandied about as being a potential disaster, enterprise agreements were a bad thing, and we did not want to go to them, we wanted to go to bigger unions for ease of negotiation.
It is interesting to see that in 1984 Senator Button said as follows:
The Opposition's policy will have the effect of weakening the role of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and encouraging decentralised bargaining.

The reason it is interesting that he said that in 1984 is that what the Government would have us believe now is that it can have it both ways; it can move towards these bigger unions with a 20,000 membership and still, in some way, cater for decentralised bargaining enterprise agreements in some form. In other words, the Government wants to have it both ways, and it just cannot.
In 1985 the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis, in referring to Mr Howard, said:
He has publicly said that he sees industrial relations as the `new economic battleground' and has a vision of thousands of Mudginberris around the country.
Australians don't want these policies. Employers don't want them. Unions don't want them. Clearly, his--
that is, Mr Howard's--
own party doesn't want them either.

It would be a good thing if we had thousands of Mudginberris around the country. If the people on the shop floor took the power they have got into their own hands and said to their unions, `You are simply not representing us in the way we want', if people could negotiate directly with their employers, that would be a good thing, and I would be happy to support it.

In 1985 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said of the Government's industrial relations approach that the hallmark of it had been `to seek outcomes which, while preserving equity, deliver the maximum feasible restraint in average outcomes for labour costs. And, as the evidence which I have presented clearly shows, our approach has been highly successful'. One could stop there, but he goes on to say, `It is understood that this may, at times, be at the cost of a degree of flexibility'.

That is the whole point. Up until about 18 months ago Labor has always criticised the coalition's policy to move towards enterprise bargaining. We agree that it would be better for employers to deal with one union, but what we say is that it need not be a 20,000-strong union, it can be a union for that particular workplace or company. That would clearly be in the better interests of the employers and employees together.
Of course, Labor has now come around. We find in 1989 Senator Button saying:

I agree absolutely that the more we can introduce flexibility into the wages system and the more we can have industry and enterprise level negotiations on wages and other matters, the better the system will be.
I could give other examples of Labor's pretty rapid road to Damascus. Some time between 1985 and now Labor purports to have discovered the value of enterprise based agreements.

But in the face of those words, the Government still presents the Senate with a Bill to limit the size of unions to a minimum of 20,000 and the interrelationship between those two sets of phrases that are trotted out by Government members has yet to be adequately explained. What I want to do is move on and explain why I think enterprise unions are better, why I think industrial relations are better when they can be conducted on a one to one basis rather than by huge, super unions that do not necessarily represent the interests of the workers.

Let me make it clear that I am not alone in this. The Federated Clerks Union of Australia, in its most recent publication, describes industry unions as a flop and it says that industry unions, where they have existed, have generally failed to organise white collar clerical and other employees, whose wages and conditions have fallen behind. The union says that, as a minority of employees in a company, white collar workers suffer neglect of their conditions where production workers dominate industry unions and it goes on to give examples of countries that have moved towards industry based unions.

Let me just select Sweden as one. The union says that, with 25 industry-type unions, Sweden is often held up as a model for Australians to follow. But Sweden's industrial production is right down to minus 3.3 and its inflation rate of 10.2 is the highest of the 13 developed countries. But, looking to what other people do is not sufficient reason or rationale to decide what we should do. I would like to turn to the following statement in the Business Council Bulletin of June 1990, where the Council said:
In the great global battles-Apple versus IBM, Coke versus Pepsi, Bond Brewing versus Fosters --
This might now perhaps be a little bit out of date. The article continued:

Australian Wool Growers versus Dupont Synthetics, Honda versus General Motors, McDonalds versus Burger King, Caterpillar versus Komatsu-the winner is not defined by country, industry or craft. The winner is the enterprise or set of enterprises best able to compete in world markets.

Those examples make it abundantly clear that a union that covers McDonalds and Burger King together is not going to be much help to McDonalds and Burger King competing against each other or competing internationally. But a union that is for McDonalds, where the McDonald workers can have their say, and another union that is for Burger King, where the workers for Burger King can have their say, and perhaps have some real contribution to make as to how the two compete, is a very sensible union. The future of the bloke who works for McDonalds depends on McDonalds doing a better job than Burger King. So why would we want to force him into a union that represents both?

That just seems sensible. As the Business Council said, the great global battles are fought on the basis of an enterprise or a group of enterprises not on an industry basis. We do not have computer unions having some reason to do a better job than say soft drink unions. That is absolutely ridiculous. Senators have to understand that the competition is at the product level, the enterprise level, enterprise to enterprise or group of enterprises to group of enterprises, and this suggestion that we are debating tonight flies totally in the face of that.

It is not only the Business Council that has this view. Power Brewing has effectively implemented what the voluntary employment agreements in Queensland would otherwise have done. An article in the Weekend Australian of 4-5 August this year, read:
In effect, Power is seeking to achieve the same result as the VEA-the exclusion of the influence of the Federated Liquor and Allied Trades Union from its Yatala brewery and 124 employees --

Now, why would that be the case? Why would the employees be happy to get rid of their union? It can only be because the union has been slack on the job. The union has not been representing the employees. It has been all about getting itself more membership and about factional battles within the Australian Council of Trade Unions, not about representing the workers. That is why we have the Mudginberri and Power Brewing cases and others.

But there is a particular example I want to raise tonight and you, Mr Acting Deputy President coming from South Australia, will no doubt be familiar with this example of a firm called Safries in the south east. It is a firm that makes chip potatoes-not crisp ones-potatoes that are cut up and sent off to fish and chip shops where they are heated up. The Adelaide Advertiser of 31 May 1990 reported:

A group of 27 women and three men employed by a South-East food company have ditched their union and negotiated one of the State's first shop-floor industrial agreements. And according to the management of the Safries potato processing plant, in Millicent, the women are teaching their bosses a thing or two about industrial relations.

Why? Because the bosses are listening to what the shop floor has to say. These people down at Safries could not give a hoot what the guy at the top of some union with 20,000 members thinks, and the reason they could not give a hoot about what he thinks is that they are pretty sure that he does not give a hoot about what they think. He does not know about their problems down in the south east and the problems that are associated with their particular enterprise at all. This enterprise agreement has turned into an absolute boon. Later in the article the employees are reported as having said:
Before all this happened we just clocked on and clocked off and went home and didn't think anything about the company.

But now they have an interest and they have an opportunity to have some say and control their lives in a way that the particular union was never going to let them do and surely that they would not have a chance of doing if the union became a strong 20,000 member union. What the women have to say about the Food Preservers Union, which was trying to negotiate an agreement-this is the union that was ditched by them-is this:
They came to Millicent, signed most of the workers up, but we never had a say in what was happening about our wages and conditions.

That pretty well says it all. That is why enterprise based agreements are better. When someone else comes in from outside, that person does not have the interests of the members at heart and does not understand how the enterprise is working. All that union representative is on about is building the union's bureaucracy. What we are seeing now is the unions trying to place the protection of their own power above the interests of workers and above that of the economy. We should very strongly resist such a move.

In conclusion, can I return to my first point-the remarks that Mr Howard made some time ago. What he said was that the sine qua non of industrial relations is not having a tidier system so that big business can negotiate with big unions, and that will be all very convenient for the Federal Government. Yes, that might be a tidier system and it might look a cleaner system, but it is not one in which workers have a greater say over their daily lives. Therefore it is not a system that I can advocate as being one that is a positive reform at all. Quite the opposite.

Members of the Labor Party should, I think, take the opportunity in their future speeches to explain exactly how they see that enterprise agreements, which they frequently mouth on the radio as being something that they want to move towards, will interplay with this arrangement that they are putting forward. I know that in the Industrial Relations Bill they have an opportunity for employers who want to opt out to do so, but that is very small cheese compared to what the coalition is talking about-all workers having a say directly in how their wages, conditions and other benefits are worked out.

—Let me just repeat. The Safries example in South Australia really is the very best example. Senator Bolkus interrupts and says he will call a point of order. Well, he could, but he would not want to because, at the Safries firm that I am talking about, the women ditched their union because it had not the slightest interest in what they wanted. SPEECH.PARA: This is the Government that says it wants to represent the workers. Why is it not representing the workers?
