SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. Once again, whenever this Hawke Labor Government brings forward industrial relations legislation to the Parliament we see the actions of the Labor Government running true to form. Whatever specious comments are made by Ministers as to the greater efficiency of the industrial relations structures, the fact remains that the substance is always legislation that first and foremost suits their political minders, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

SPEECH.PARA: What did we have in 1987 but legislation that was so blatantly sectional, seeking to deprive the victims of union action of their common law rights, that this Government was forced to drop it in the trash can in order to survive the 1987 election. In 1988 the industrial relations legislation that was passed may not have dared to set unions above the law, but it was certainly a self-serving exercise that was aimed at easier amalgamations, just as the ACTU wanted.

Today we have the Government coming back for another bite at the amalgamation cherry, in what will mean a strengthening of those bureaucratic forces on the industrial relations scene that will retard the development of enterprise-based and productive arrangements. That is a very sad day for Australia because from here on in we go backwards.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has made predictable remarks about greater efficiency and a supposed enterprise orientation of these changes in outlining the fact that about 100 of the current 149 federally registered unions either will disappear or will exist at the discretion of the Industrial Relations Commission. It is freely admitted that the onus will be on these smaller unions to justify their existence. Thus, the principle of freedom of association is crudely discounted by this Bill.

This is exactly where there is so firm a policy difference between the Hawke Labor Government and the Australian Democrats who accept the same principle against the coalition. I am proud to uphold the principle of freedom of association for employees, whether to belong to any union, to decide which union may best represent them, or to form their own union. That is where the Government and the Democrats combine and will never ever have the same attitude as the coalition. I am most disturbed to think that the Democrats on this occasion are yet again siding with the Government to bring about the demise of what we see as the ultimate goal for the employees.

Let us not fall into the trap set by this Government and confuse the wholly desirable formation of enterprise unions with the encouragement of amalgamations by this kind of coercive legislation. Amalgamations are not about efficiency or better industrial relations. They are simply about power, and we should not forget what this is all about. The ACTU wants more power and the Government is seeking to give it to that body.

This is exactly what Mr Kelty told us in 1987 in his paper Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement. He made it clear then that the ACTU objective was not the formation of industry unions but `the unionisation of all employees in a company'. With only 32 per cent of all private sector employees currently unionised, we can appreciate his even greater sense of priority today. I again quote Mr Kelty:
I want to unionise not just part of the company but all of the company.
That is the motive of the ACTU in requiring this Labor Government to bring forward this Bill, and one should never forget it. Its desire is just simply not negotiable.

The ACTU in 1987 spelt out its objective of just 20 unions and made it equally plain that productive efficiency was not the motivation. What Mr Kelty wants is greater control, not even by union officials as a whole but ultimately by the ACTU leadership and its bureaucracy.

Mr Kelty in recent years has sniffed the wind overseas where better skilled and better paid workers are finding unions irrelevant and has sounded the warning that once unionisation falls to 20 to 25 per cent of the work force the influence of unions in national power structures passes the point of no return. Quite deliberately, therefore, he has sought to consolidate and institutionalise union power in Australia, with the key players of the ACTU setting the agenda for the handful of massive unions through control of such paid positions as secretary, research and education officers.

Consolidation of large unions is a sure means of entrenching existing holders of power, as it becomes extremely difficult for an effective challenge to be mounted against office-holders. The cost, for example, of sending just one circular to a membership of 100,000 would effectively start at $60,000. A number of smaller unions under the control of politically inconvenient moderates would, of course, disappear.

This legislation with its objective of forcing amalgamations, far from moving towards an enterprise approach, is a recipe for less control and influence by the rank and file. We can be sure, however, that the ACTU objectives that I have outlined are being concealed from the membership whose choices will be limited if the Bill is passed.

The Bill, if passed, will make impossible the already difficult task of establishing new unions when existing bodies, through their political stance, may be anathema to prospective members, or when workers see a need to form a genuine enterprise union at grass roots level. Existing industrial relations bureaucracy has already prevented the formation of an alternative union for teachers. Now we have a Bill before the Senate that will make a further mockery of article 2 of the International Labour Organisation that supposedly enshrines the right of workers to join organisations of their own choosing.

Two years ago when the Senate last debated a major change to industrial law, the Democrats shied away from an arbitrary minimum size of 3,000 that was then proposed by this Government and joined the coalition in forcing it down to 1,000. Today, it is a different story. Clauses 12 and 14 of this Bill seek to raise the minimum to 20,000 and, predictably, the Democrats tell us that a figure of 10,000 has become acceptable. What a conversion! Once again, it is thunderously apparent that the Democrats have no understanding either of industrial realities or of any principles.

All this Labor Government needs to do is to take a ball park figure and the Democrats will fall into line with an acceptable compromise. They do it all the time, we have got used to it but on this occasion it is particularly sad. Can we ask the Democrats why industrial realities have changed so much in two years that a 1,000 minimum, which was acceptable two years ago, should be raised tenfold today? They would not be able to answer because they do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few extra trips overseas.

—I suppose, Senator Macdonald, that is right. A few extra trips overseas would be very handy. Of course, the Democrats always want extra staff. They grizzle and complain that they have not enough staff. But they have more extra staff than one can poke a stick at and they still cannot do the job.

SPEECH.PARA: A minimum size of 10,000 will eliminate some 90 of the 149 unions to which I referred earlier. The Government's limit of 20,000 would eliminate a further 12. Halving the figure does not, therefore, make a great deal of practical difference. But the Government and the Democrats have seen fit to hold hands yet again.

I challenge the proponents of this Bill to justify it on the grounds that existing legislation makes amalgamation difficult when such is the wish of the membership. I challenge them to tell us just where the present system is thwarting genuine rationalisation of union coverage that this Bill will rectify. The facts are that amalgamations can take place under the existing rules and they do already. Nor are unions prevented from coming to agreements to secure rationalisation of coverage at particular plants with 12 different unions, for example, clearing out of Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd and leaving four.

What is a fact under this Bill is that the kind of rationalisation of which the ACTU does not approve will in fact be prevented. Single enterprise agreements, notably by the ironworkers, have been concluded successfully through existing section 118 of the Act. Thus the Full Bench of the Commission ratified the Southern Aluminium agreement of Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia coverage of a new site to the exclusion of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and the Electrical Trades Union of Australia in December 1989.

This is the kind of decision that does seek to eliminate demarcation disputes and may even point the way to the `single union no strike' deals that have been concluded in Britain by the forward thinking electricians union, much to the ire of Neanderthal union bureaucrats, I might add. It is equally clear that this is not what the ACTU wants. If ever there was any doubt as to the retrograde nature of this Bill, it is the new requirement that in approving such agreements the Australian Industrial Relations Commission shall, under section 118, consult the peak union councils. In simple terms, the ACTU will get the power of veto. That is what it wants. That is its whole aim and objective in this exercise and one must not forget it.

This Government has no concern whatsoever to promote enterprise agreements or single union coverage when it deliberately gives its ACTU paymasters the power to thwart such agreements. Moreover, the coalition is equally opposed to the strengthening under this Bill of preference clauses or the reduction of the need for postal balloting. Both of these are actions that impinge further on freedom of individual choice and erode freedom from possible intimidation.

Senator Sherry launched the most unbelievable first speech this afternoon. He said that only the Australian Labor Party stands for democracy. Yet it is the Labor Party that seeks to remove the right of secret postal ballots by unionists. That is some strange frame of democracy. Yet Labor members say they are the only ones who believe in it. Both these actions proposed in the Bill have nothing to do with the interests of unionists but everything to do with the conveniences of the big unions and, of course, the ACTU.

Whenever a Labor government presents legislation to achieve ACTU-driven mergers we are told that the legislation will make life easier for business in eliminating demarcation disputes. This is simply a massive red herring. We know it, and I am sure the Government and the Democrats know it. The sad reality is that we are the only ones to admit to it and to talk about it. This Bill in no way alters the system of craft unions to replace them with industry unions, the only sure means of tackling this problem.

If the Government was determined to have good unionism here, it would take a trip to Japan for example and look at the system the Japanese have with unions. It would have a look at how few strikes they have. Senator Sherry has the gall to shake his head. I bet he has never even been to Japan to look at the union set-up there. He should go and ask the major corporations when they had their last strike. They would not believe that he could even ask such a question. But that depicts this Government's mentality-its lack of understanding about unionism, industrial relations and how the system can work to the benefit of this country. The one thing that we learnt from Senator Sherry this afternoon was that he does not know what he purports to be here for and that is rather sad.

It is instructive that Australia's employer organisations are not fooled by this grubby exercise in entrenching union bureaucracies. In July the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) stated firmly that what employers want are industry and enterprise unions, and that union size is irrelevant in achieving this goal. And what does the Government do? It dishes up this piece of legislation. The CAI has rightly accused the Hawke Labor Government of pursuing the wrong end for the wrong reasons, moving from what was a minimum membership requirement of 100 prior to 1988 to a possibility of 20,000.

If Australia is to have improved productivity, there must be scope for single union agreements of the kind that exist in Britain. This will not be brought about by amalgamations, and true restructuring on enterprise lines may well result in the formation of smaller unions. The adoption of size as the criterion for viability shows up the limitations of the thinking of this Government and its masters, the ACTU. It is the CAI rather than the ACTU that is upholding the principle that trade unions are associations of employees; employees should have the right to control their structures and future. This is a right that the Bill will erode and business efficiency will not be the winner.

The Business Council of Australia is described as the voice of the major corporations which might be thought to favour amalgamations, but in May the Business Council bulletin politely knocked the legs from under the Government's case. But did the Government take any notice of that? Of course not. The only people who it takes any notice of are members of the ACTU. The point was made that the existence of small unions is not the main element of the bargaining union problem. The problem, as the coalition has stated so often, is the system of craft unions and the award structure that has been created to serve their interests.

It is pointed out that amalgamations as sought by this Bill will not change the fact that of the 12 unions that predominate in Business Council companies, nine or 10 would remain. Their membership has an average coverage per plant ranging from 5 to 53 per cent, a very long way short of the single union ideal. The simple fact is stated that these moves are not designed to create industry unions but that factional and political allegiance appear likely to be at least as important determinants of amalgamations as industry compatibility.

This legislation cannot alter the fact that craft unions have spread their membership over thousands of workplaces and the consequences will remain. The Government and the ACTU by their actions are not committed to a workplace approach and the potential for demarcation disputes will unquestionably remain while there is an average of five unions per workplace and of 11 in larger plants. The Government is happy with that. Yet it knows that a totally different system works better and more successfully.

A slight reduction in this average is not going to create the enterprise focus that is essential for better industrial relations and competitive industries. In the name of greater flexibility, this Bill will create self-interested, inflexible cartels that will act as a barrier to sensible agreements between management and employees or intelligent union leaders and to the formation of genuine enterprise unions. These are the objectives to which the coalition stands committed and more Australians are realising that this is the only sensible policy for the future. But in this piece of legislation we are quite clearly going backwards and we should not forget that it is quite willingly supported by the Democrats.

This legislation is the result of the failure of contemporary Australian unionism to make itself relevant to today's work force and Mr Kelty has revealed why it is so important for the ACTU to consolidate its power. The statistics show that between 1976 and 1988 trade union membership of Australian employees fell from 51 per cent to 42 per cent. Within the private sector that has to provide the engines of growth for the national economy, unionisation has fallen in the six years from 1982 to 1988 from 39 per cent to 32 per cent compared with a fall from 73 per cent to 68 per cent in the public sector.

ACTU apparatchiks, such as Mr Kelty, cannot speak for the Australian work force, least of all for the majority of employees involved in earning the export dollars that keep this country afloat. Therefore, in my opinion it is a scandal that this Labor Government, with the collusion of the Democrats, is set to enshrine ACTU dominance over the unions when members of the work force are voting with their feet against this approach. The Government that purports to represent the working class and the workers yet fraternises with the Sir Peter Abeles of this world and all the big businessmen around the country could not give a continental about what is really going to affect the workers out there.

The difference between the coalition policy and that of its Labor and Democrats opponents is the difference between institutionalising the dominance of craft unions and opening up the prospect of enterprise unions. It is the difference between increasing the power of a handful of ACTU power brokers and providing free choice and freedom of association to the employees. It is the difference between rigidity and flexibility, and I have no doubt as to which approach is best for Australia.

The coalition will fight this vigorously both within this Parliament and outside in the public arena, because the people of Australia need to know what this Government is doing to this country. They know that we are already going down the mine shaft with a tail wind, and this will help it go further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I urge the Government and the Australian Democrats to seriously consider the results of the proposals set out in the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and take heed of the warnings that my colleagues have so clearly and forcefully put in this debate so far. In particular, I urge the Government to rethink the plans to increase the membership threshold for registration of unions from 1,000 to 20,000 members.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government in Queensland has taken a number of decisions which, along with the proposals that we are now considering, have set the genuine union movement back many years. The Cooke Inquiry into union corruption and the Goss Government's repeal of voluntary employment agreements (VEAs) are two matters of significant concern to the real interests of workers.

This Bill says, `We want big unions and fewer unions, and we do not want them to be inconvenienced by such things as secret ballots for all members on such pithy issues as amalgamation or where the union's money should be going'. What happens when we have big unions and less accountability? The consequences of this are only too clear to those of us from Queensland. What we have seen in Queensland is an ALP State Vice-President, Ken Goodhew, and his mates, abuse their position on the executive of the Federated Engine Drivers Association of Australasia. We have seen slush funds used to buy Gold Coast apartments and to pay for prostitutes-a misappropriation of union members' funds to an extent that is almost unimaginable. In the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia, mismanagement amounted to more than $1m unaccounted for as well as consistent evidence of ballots being rorted.

It would not really matter who the unions donated their money to if it were done with the consent of their members, but when a union donates the funds of its members-as we have seen the liquor trades union do-to the election campaigns of two Labor Ministers in Queensland, Bob Gibbs and Anne Warner, without so much as even notifying their membership let alone giving them a say in it, then that union is no longer performing its rightful duty, which is to look after the conditions of its members in the workplace. These things are on the record and I suggest that the Cooke Inquiry has merely scratched the surface of some of the rorts and frauds that have gone on in the union movement.

If the Cooke Inquiry is permitted to continue by the ALP Government in Queensland, there is little doubt that further revelations will come out which will do irreparable damage to the increasingly fragile credibility of a party, the ALP, that shot to power in Queensland on a platform of honesty and accountability. The things that I have mentioned here are just a hint of what happens when officers of a big union are given too much free rein.

Many factors are responsible for the rise of these problems, and I shall identify just a couple of them. The biggest seem to be those factors which result from the size of the union. The bigger the union, the easier it is to get away with irresponsible conduct, and the easier it is to avoid any of one's members knowing anything about it. In a larger union the average member has far less contact with office-bearers and less efficient representation by the union on his or her behalf in the workplace. Second, of course, is the accountability issue and the very concerning absence of secret ballots on decisions so important as the donation of union funds to political parties. There is also the factor of size and accountability that makes the unions neglect their real duties in preference for spending time and money pursuing internal left versus right factional battles.

This Bill fails to address the problems which are rife in unions all over the country. In fact, they go a long way to encouraging a climate where union corruption can flourish. As Senator Harradine pointed out in a recent press release, this Bill will force some 632,000 workers, or 18.6 per cent of the total membership, out of their unions and into another union- a larger union which will almost certainly understand the needs of these new members less than the smaller enterprise-based unions did.

The Liberal Party is not anti-union: we want more unions. We want unions-be they of 50 members or 25,000 members-that are enterprise-based unions more concerned about the working conditions and particular needs of their members than about wasting resources on factional battles and power broking. We want unions to take the lead in the search for productivity gains that benefit the employee and the employer. The Federal Government should take a good hard look at the results of the policy decisions which the Queensland Government has recently made. Instead of encouraging productivity gains and enterprise-based agreements, which have benefited the employers and the employees, we have seen a big bold step back into the dark ages in Queensland-those dark ages of industrial chaos which we in Queensland had to put up with during the South East Queensland Electricity Board (SEQEB) dispute prior to the introduction of VEAs in our State. With the abolition of VEAs at the end of this month, hundreds of Queensland workers will be worse off. With the removal of VEAs, SEQEB workers will be $60 to $70 per week poorer.

I must congratulate Senator Sherry on his speech this afternoon. It was a very lucid speech on his view on industrial relations and other matters-a view, of course, which we do not share but which he put very well from his point of view. He raised the point of the poor little workers going into a big room with the employer and all his lawyers and being browbeaten into submission on some deals that they did not really want. I suggest to Senator Sherry and members of his party that he should ask the workers at Power Brewing, or the SEQEB workers, or the Metway Bank workers, or ask the workers of 25 other companies which adopted VEAs, whether they thought they were being browbeaten and stood over when they were getting so much more in their pay packets. That is what it is all about. They were doing much better because they were working out with their employers what was best for their industry, and they were sharing in the profits that the increased productivity brought.

These workers in Queensland, who had VEAs and were very happy with them, are being made to suffer. Why are they being made to suffer, losing $60, $70 or $80 a week out of their pay packets? Simply to pay back the big unions that supported Wayne Goss and the Australian Workers Union conservative right wing faction of the Queensland ALP. This is a great example of big unions looking after themselves and not giving a damn about their memberships.

The bosses of a number of Queensland unions were scared stiff of their members waking up to the better conditions being experienced by workers who had VEAs in the companies I have spoken of. It is very disturbing to see the same thing being proposed at a Federal level as we have had at a State level in Queensland. The Federal Government wants to pay back Bill Kelty and his mates for their loyal support by rounding up the unions and killing off the smaller ones and those with minds of their own, so that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) can have complete control of the industrial relations system.

I find it amazing that the ALP thinks it can get away with this grab for power by using the argument that a mere reduction in the number of unions will lead to more efficient industrial relations negotiations in the workplace and that employers want this legislation for this reason.

The Business Council of Australia's survey on the subject showed that amalgamations would not reduce the number of demarcation disputes. Most of those presently happening occur between the bigger unions, in any case.

I am disappointed, but not really surprised, to learn of the Democrats' back flip on this legislation as they back flip on so many matters. It was only a couple of years ago that they opposed the Government's proposal to increase the minimum union membership to 3,000. They are now saying that 10,000 is probably okay. What has changed? Could it be that this time the only difference is that the Government and the ACTU have put together a better backroom deal for the Democrats? Could it be that they have offered better carrots than they were able to offer before? It is possible that the ACTU and the Government do not really expect to get the minimum membership to 20,000 this year, but they have probably aimed high knowing that the Democrats will do a deal and will compromise. In a year or two, the Government may introduce another amendment providing for, say, a 40,000 member threshold, comfortable in the knowledge that, provided it gives the right carrots away, the Democrats will again compromise and the Government can then get back to the 20,000 that maybe it was looking at. In the end, it matters not a great deal whether it is 20,000 or 10,000, the outcome is pretty much the same. It is a bit like the old adage that someone would be better off being hit by a 50 tonne truck than by a 100 tonne truck.

The Democrats have a responsibility to the people to use their power sensibly. They should forget the backroom deals with the ACTU. If the Democrats pass this Bill, they will have to live with the consequences, which my colleagues and I have spelt out very clearly. The Australian public-the workers and the genuine unionists-should be made aware that it was the Democrats who again sold them down the drain.

I urge the Government to take the Bill away, think about the matters my colleagues have so sensibly raised in this debate, and bring back a Bill that encourages enterprise-based unions and voluntary employment agreements so that the workers of Australia get some real worth out of the unions they pay for so handsomely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for very long. I foreshadow some matters that I hope the Government will take into account between now, the second reading stage, and when the Senate considers the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my intention to vote for the Bill at the second reading stage in the hope that there will be time for the Government to consider some aspects of its effects on a number of individual unions. If the Government does not consider that, it is my intention to vote against certain provisions of this legislation in the Committee of the Whole.

Although I do not think it necessary, I mention that I probably have a vested interest in this matter as I am President of one of the largest unions in my State and Honorary Secretary of one of the smallest unions, which, being a very small union, is not registered under the Industrial Relations Act. However, the large union is registered under the Act and probably stands to gain from this legislation fairly substantially.

I consider that the action being proposed by the Government ultimately to deregister unions with fewer than 20,000 members will in fact force 638,000 workers, or 18.6 per cent of the total union members, out of their unions and into other unions. This is industrially naive and disregards the rights of workers; that is, their rights to freedom of association under the International Labour Organisation convention. My problem with this legislation is very similar to the problem I had with the legislation that Mr Viner introduced into the Parliament some years ago. When the legislation got to this chamber, this chamber established a Senate industrial relations committee, of which I became Chairman. The problem with both the Viner legislation and this legislation is that they view union restructuring, such as amalgamation of industry or enterprise unions, as something of a panacea that will bring about improved industrial relations. But the industrial fact of life is that industrial relations outcomes are determined more by the desire of the parties to see that an industrial relations system works than by the size of individual unions.

In fact, as a result of this legislation, there could be the enhancement of careerist leadership of unions. Careerist leadership of giant conglomerate unions, as envisaged under this legislation, aloof from the rank and file and oblivious to the rights of the members of the other unions, could cause havoc to industrial relations outcomes.

To force, as is envisaged by this legislation, hundreds of thousands of union members out of their unions into other unions is a denial of workers' rights. Many unionists who are members of the smaller unions of under 20,000 have a long association with those unions and have developed a loyalty to them and to their fellow members within those organisations-a deep sense of belonging. This will be taken away by the Government's legislation, and I cannot accept that. I wonder whether the Government has written to all of the unions likely to be affected by this legislation. If it has done so, what are the responses coming back to it?

I am conscious of the need, if it is at all possible, to cut down the work of industrial tribunals and others that consider that because of the number of unions involved that their workload is more than it would otherwise be. I am not so sure that that is the case. In my experience it is often better to have, in a particular trade, an industrial award that covers smaller organisations with union members whose representatives know what they are talking about and are able to put their case cogently before the industrial tribunal rather than have to rely on, as it were, professional representation.

Over many years we have had this argument within the trade union movement as to what constitutes industrial unions, and still there has been no agreed definition within the trade union movement as to what constitutes an industrial union. It really comes down to a concept of what is big is best. I do not agree with that. We used to hear the argument advanced that amalgamation would overcome demarcation disputes. Well, it may and it may not. Let me remind the chamber that one of the biggest demarcation disputes ever followed the amalgamation of the Amalgamated Engineering Union and the Boilermakers and Blacksmiths Society of Australia. A dispute arose on the west coast of Tasmania as to whether a fitter member of the new union or a boilermaker member of the new union would cut a bolt.

The Minister knows as well as I do that these proposals contained in the Bill are not necessarily a guarantee for a better industrial relations outcome. I conclude on an appeal that the Minister take the opportunity between now and when this Bill will be considered in the Committee of the Whole to contact all unions likely to be affected by the legislation so that those organisations will be able to consult their membership thoroughly and respond to the Minister, and through him, to the chamber. It may well be that he has already done so. I do not know. Obviously, he will be able to let the Senate know when he rises to respond to this second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This debate relates to the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1990. It is a Bill to amend the Industrial Relations Act to encourage and facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions. It has a number of other amendments, most notably an amendment that has been the subject of debate in this chamber which sets out in fuller detail the provisions that would be required of a preference direction in the Act to the Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable senators have made sound and sober contributions to the debate and I thank all those who have contributed. It is a Bill of some importance, given that it talks about the structure of one of the major agents in the social process in Australia-the trade union movement. It is a Bill that has arisen from an exhaustive series of consultations through the National Labour Consultative Council (NLCC), a body which is tripartite in nature, a body consisting of members of the Australian Government, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). It is a consultative process that was commenced after each of the relevant organisations-not just those that I have named but organisations with a particular interest in this field both on the union side and on the employer side-were notified of change and invited to contribute to the Government its views about the course of that change.

The consultations in the form of the legislative committee of the NLCC took nearly three full working days to complete, were exhaustive in their scope and detailed in their consideration. Finally, the committee was unanimous about the purpose contained in the objectives of this Bill, although it is right to say that that unanimity did not extend to each of the particular measures, that the Government has chosen in its wisdom to propose, as amendments. Indeed, it should be said that the Confederation of Australian Industry was reserved about a number of features, most notably and publicly the feature of our amendments that prescribe a minimum size of unions.

I want to turn to the remarks of a number of speakers in this debate. Before I do, perhaps I should deal with the remarks of the last speaker, Senator Harradine, who is an independent member of this chamber, who has exercised his independence over a series of governments and who, prior to being elected to this chamber, had a long and, dare I say it, distinguished career as a union official. His criticisms carry more weight than the criticisms that might be made by others. His question was: have we written to each particular union that may be affected? I say in answer to that question that, before we began the process, we conducted an exhaustive array of consultations notifying all of the interested groups that we were starting it, that we were going to pursue it and that we were inviting their comments on it. I can also report to the Senate that I am not aware of one individual union which has brought forward a particular criticism of the course we have embarked on, or the conclusions we have arrived at, notably the minimum size of unions. No-one has written to us about that or notified us of it.

The process of consultation is essential and it is a process that this Government is noted for; in fact, it is the raison d'etre for this Government being elected in terms of its industrial relations position. While that process is important, in the final phase of that search for consensus the Government must make a decision and must work and live by that decision. I invite Senator Harradine to debate with me, either privately or in this chamber at the committee stage, whether, in searching for consensus, that process cannot be one in which the consensus is at the lowest common denominator, or in which the smallest union with an objection about its fate under these amendments holds all of the organisations back in the making of a decision. I am sure, knowing characteristically that Senator Harradine is an ardent advocate of a particular point of view which he decides on, that he and I will have the opportunity to join more closely in that debate.

There is something unique about the Senate from a government point of view. That uniqueness is that this chamber, and this chamber exclusively, does not have a Government majority. It is possible in this chamber that government legislation can be defeated. That is why it is true to say of the Hawke Government that, for all of its years in office, it has not been in power because the power has resided in the Senate. The power to obstruct, change or alter the course of key legislation exists here.

It is for those reasons that I have listened particularly closely to the arguments advanced in this legislation. I say as an observer-if I may confer that status upon myself for a moment-that it is particularly notable that the Australian Democrats have supported the substance of the amendments we seek, although not in all cases the detail, and have reserved their rights to make what I regard as heavy criticism of some of the detail in terms of the degree in which the Government wishes to apply those provisions.

The Australian Democrats have conducted an informed debate on this Bill. But I do not concede and I will not concede at this stage that their arguments are true as to the proposals they have advanced. We cleave to this legislation because it is necessary in the national economic interest and it is essential to achieving the micro-economic reform that all parties in this Parliament argue is the direction in which Australia needs to go.

There is an importance as well to build into this legislation incentives for change. In the end we can observe nothing more than resolutions for change but not actions on those resolutions unless there are incentives to make the final commitment to find a better way to alter to the better course.

I must acknowledge that in the debate Senator McLean, representing the Australian Democrats, made a constructive and, I would regard, principled argument, the basis of which I respect; nonetheless, I disagree with it. I will pursue the opportunities that exist between now and in the committee stage to argue out those issues with him and other Democrats as well.

Honourable senators should contrast that to the role of the Opposition. Members of the Opposition have not sought to be constructive; they have not sought to raise principled argument; they have not sought a basis of knowledge on which to fashion rationality; nor have they commanded particular respect by the way in which they have put their views. The Opposition, comprised as a coalition of the National Party and the Liberal Party, led by John Hewson, represented in industrial relations by John Howard and represented here by Senator Durack, aspire collectively as a group to be the alternative government of this country. What they say on industrial relations should carry a particular force; ergo, what they do not say should also contain a particular force.

Many things have not been said in this debate which would, by their very nature of not being addressed and being omitted by design, stand as a criticism of the hollowness and emptiness of many of the Opposition's views. For those who aspire to be an alternative are bound not only to say what they oppose but also are bound to say what they stand for and how circumstances would be different or, in their view, better if they had the opportunity to do that.

They have failed that test on industrial relations because their arguments have been mostly inspired by vague, ideological meanderings, by uninformed comment about the nature of industrial relations; indeed, in particular places of key importance, by prejudice, by bigotry and by an ignorance or envy, as articulated just this afternoon by Senator Grant Chapman in respect of Mr Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as if tackling the man not the ball is some sort of argument for rationality. They have done this at a time in which the Australian electorate knows-because this is one thing as a policy initiative they have proclaimed-that if they are elected next time, they intend to introduce a consumption tax. It is rumoured by those journalists who seem to have access to the internal workings of the Opposition that the level of that consumption tax will be about 15 per cent.

So at a time in which members of the Opposition have had an opportunity to lay out an industrial relations alternative, and we know that there would be a consumption tax of the order of 15 per cent if they were elected, they have not answered-and this is an opportunity for them to do so-what the world would look like in grappling with that supercharge to inflation in a decentralised, uncoordinated workplace-by-workplace negotiation system such as they have proposed.

The Government wants this legislation because it will encourage one bargaining unit per workplace. The recent survey by the Business Council of Australia (BCA) showed that for workplaces of between 100 and 500 employees there are at least five unions; beyond 2,000 employees there are up to 11 unions. The ACTU believes that that should be rationalised.

We agree that it is ideal to have in one workplace one bargaining unit representing the interests of all. This would enable the removal of demarcation, flexibility in the use of labour, proper training to be introduced and multiskilling. This would be the basis of increased productivity and future wage negotiations on how that productivity, once achieved, is best shared. That is the basis of accord mark 6-a move to more direct bargaining in the workplace, given that, nonetheless, while one is decentralising from a central system, there is a requirement on a government in the public interest and because of human compassion to see that the weakest in the workplace are protected by some central constructs on wage fixation.

The Government in this legislation seeks to give a union organisational coherence to micro-economic reform by encouraging the development of industry unions in industries-a development that we see as particularly important. That is our position. It is fundamental to achieving rationality in the union structure. From the point of view of unions being free associations democratically comprised, that is an essential change. But from the economic point of view, the wider public interest point of view, the point of view of a more vibrant economy, the achievement of the micro-economic reform benefits that this legislation brings is important as well.

There are at least five points of condemnation to the Liberal position. The Liberal's theory of union structures for this country is just that-a theory. It has no support. There is no support from unions and there is no broad support for it from employer organisations. The BCA, the closest organisation to its viewpoint, does not explicitly endorse this particular plan that the Opposition proposes; in fact, the BCA has distanced itself from the more gung ho elements of Opposition expression. Firstly, is there support? The answer is no. Secondly, is there a model elsewhere in the world that we can look at for the Opposition's structure? The answer is no. John Howard admitted that at a seminar I attended with him held by the Australian Financial Review earlier this year. What he has instead is an eclectic gathering of various elements of different systems which he has chosen the best of, rejected the balance of, and then said that this is a new structure.

There is a reference in rhetoric to Japan. The structure being talked of by the Opposition is not Japanese and it ignores the essential structure of the Japanese system as if a culturally different nation from Australia could travel its system across the Pacific to here and impose it anyway. The Opposition has failed to acknowledge that, while it is true that there are enterprise unions in that country, they are organised into federations and central councils of federations. So from a different approach one gets the same construction as we have in Australia.

Thirdly, is there a model that we can examine? The answer is no. Fourthly, is there a theoretical base to the Opposition's ideological meanderings? The closest it might be said to a theoretical underpinning of its argument might be the report entitled Transforming Industrial Relations in New South Wales: a Green Paper by Professor John Niland to the New South Wales Government for its amendments last year. But there are things in the Niland report that the New South Wales Government chose and others that it rejected. So it is unfair to John Niland to say that the position adopted by the Federal Opposition reflects his position.

Let me give the Senate one example. He has argued in his report to the New South Wales Government that limited immunity from common law activity is necessary if we are to have the type of system that he proposes-workplace negotiations and small enterprise unions. That element, essential to the overall, was rejected.

Is there a theoretical underpinning for the Opposition's position? No. Has the Opposition advanced a plan to implement its proposals? It has not. It is opposed by unions; it is not supported by employers; it confronts the Industrial Relations Commission and turns it into a marginal organisation or, worse, one that is impotent. Any aspiring government must have a huge credibility gap when it shows that it has an unsupported theory with no theoretical base and with no plan for its implementation.

As I said earlier, the consumption tax which the Opposition has said that it will implement will be a positive decision to escalate inflation in this country. Without an accord with the trade union movement, how is it to contain that inflation within a wages policy outcome, as is essential to our economic well-being?

Of course, we know from the Opposition that it will go down what it perceives to be the Thatcher road of deregulation and decentralisation on this front and abandon any prospect of an accord. So the economic underpinning necessary to ensure that tax discounting of consumption tax impositions does not break out into higher inflation and higher wages will not be there. The Thatcher road is now epitomised by a movement to double digit wages and double digit price growth in England, at levels above those which pertained under the last British Labor Government a decade ago.

Fifthly and perhaps lastly, does the Opposition have a record of achievement in this field to justify confidence by the community in its alternative model? One has only to look back at the record of the Fraser Government, a record of double digit unemployment, double digit inflation and massive industrial dislocation in this country to appreciate that one of the reasons why the electors of Australia chose the Hawke Government in March 1983 was that they wanted national reconciliation, national reconstruction and a turning away from the divisive nature of Liberal Party practice in industrial relations. That was a key plank in the election of this Government.

Is there a record of confidence? Is there a record to justify confidence? There is not. All of the electoral surveys show that voters in the Australian community regard a Labor government as better equipped than a Liberal government to handle industrial relations matters. All the public opinion surveys in the period running up to the 1983 election showed that what the community wanted was a government that could deliver relative industrial calm and a situation in which dispute matters were sorted out.

I conclude this element of my speech by saying that there is no support, there is no model, there is no underpinning theory, there is no plan, and there is no record upon which the Liberal Party alternative, advanced as it has been in the second reading debate, can have any standing whatsoever. For an Opposition which aspires to government, that is a massive condemnation.

It must be remembered also that the Liberal Party and the National Party-the coalition-have chosen this course of making themselves irrelevant to the main debate. It is a free choice. They have positively sought irrelevance by putting themselves at arm's length from employer organisations, unions and the general body of community support. When one considers the massive changes that are taking place in industrial relations in Australia -changes which are important for this country-one must see those changes as representing a great effort at reconstruction; a great effort at orderly, structured, debated and worked out change.

By comparison, the true radicals- those who wish to jettison the tried and true principles, who wish to throw over the system of arbitration that has stood this country in good stead for the last century; those without support, without theory, without model, without plan and without record; those who wish to disown the practice of industrial relations and the managed reform that this Government is working through with the unions and the employers in this country-are the Opposition. They have created in their industrial relations meanderings a bastard child of industrial relations: ill-conceived, unformed, impractical, without precedent and, more importantly, dangerous, if the Thatcher model is to be seen as something close to what they seek.

A number of other matters have been raised in this debate, many of them arising from the instinct to find the red herring or the instinct to promote ignorance rather than reason and rationality. The first is the contention that somehow big is bad and small is beautiful. The second is the contention that the International Labor Organisation (ILO) convention on the freedom of association is being disdained by this legislation. The third is the suggestion that preference is abhorrent, and the fourth is the personalised attack upon the Secretary of the ACTU.

As my time has almost elapsed I shall deal quickly with each of those. Senator Chapman in his contribution today could see no logical inconsistency when he referred to the criticism by the Business Council of Australia of the minimum size of unions under this legislation being 20,000 members. He then argued that big is bad, and because the Business Council of Australia had said this he cited it for support. He saw no illogicality in the fact that the organisation which represents the 200 largest companies in this country argues that big is bad. But it argues that only for the unions; it does not argue it for itself. The logical inconsistency is that if it believed its rhetoric, it would apply that rhetoric to its members and break down its organisations into small companies. It would disband its organisations. If those opposite preach that big is bad and join the Business Council in its view, they too are responsible for that illogicality.

Well, big is not bad; big depends on how things are organised. This Government preaches that an organisation should be flat; that the number of people between the rank and file and the leadership should be a minimum; that the democratic control of organisations is a key characteristic in determining whether they function well or not. We would go further and say that it is desirable under this legislation that the organisational focus of a rational trade union structure should be on the enterprise. If that is the way in which it operates, it will indeed be a positive advantage to this community.

The 'big is bad' argument tends to ignore a series of five separate reports over some 13 years commissioned by Liberal and Labor governments on technological change in the manufacturing sector and on industrial relations generally. Let me cite them: the report of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry in 1975; the report of the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia in 1980; the report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, set up by the Fraser Government in 1977; the report of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems set up by our Government in 1985; and the Pappas Carter study on Australian manufacturing industry set up just this year.

All of those reports, based on a wide body of evidence, synthesising the arguments and drawing conclusions, found that it is desirable to achieve a reduction in the number of unions in Australia and to rationalise those unions along industry lines to enable them to service the needs of their members, to enable the artificial constraints of demarcation in the workplace to be broken down, and to achieve one bargaining unit per workplace. That is the advice given to governments based on a body of considered inquiry. The Fraser Government took no notice of it; we intend to listen to it. We intend to enact it. Our preference, as I have said, is that the union organisation have an industry focus.

This afternoon in the debate to which I listened closely, one of the arguments raised was that somehow we were offending ILO conventions, freedom of association conventions, and the rights of the individual. This argument was espoused by a number of Opposition senators, most notably and ludicrously by Senator O'Chee. I do not like being lectured by conservatives about the rights of individuals because their history is to ignore those rights when given the chance. The freedom of association convention was brought down by the ILO in 1948. It waited 25 years through the long somnolence of the Menzies Government, through the Holt Government, through the Gorton Government, through the McMahon Government, until the Whitlam Government in 1973 adopted it.

The freedom of association convention exists in Australia because a Labor government put it there. Now I am lectured from the Opposition that we are somehow breaking our own standards. The basis of that convention is to recognise the inherent rights of voluntary association by unions. The plan advanced by the Opposition in terms of one union per enterprise is a plan which, at its base, has the belief that one can somehow impose that structure on the existing structure and abrogate the voluntary nature of the association of the existing structure. Those who claim freedom of association on the one hand are, by virtue of their own policy, talking about its direct and blatant abrogation.

What we have done is to say that there should be an amendment to the Act so that there would be a minimum size of unions of 20,000, and that that is a matter for the Industrial Relations Commission to determine because, if unions can make a particular case, then they can be excluded from that base. We have also said that there is no offence against freedom of association because that would require some sort of regulation of the right of unions to be disbarred from entry to State jurisdictions. That is not proposed; unions have that right and, if they choose it, it is there. Thirdly, we have said that, after all, unions are voluntary associations, that what they choose to do with their registration or otherwise is a matter for them, and that that is their free choice. But if they want to be registered with the Commission, there is the choice about what is the national interest. That is the choice that also should be considered.

Finally, if this argument of freedom of association had any force, it would have been trotted out last time, because the Act provides for a minimum size of 1,000. If those who argue for freedom of association are right, that is illegal. It has never been challenged. It is not illegal; it stands; it exists; and it is correct.

The most shameful element of this debate has been the personal attack upon the Secretary of the ACTU. If honourable senators opposite do not have an argument, they attack the man. If they do not have a case, they argue the individual. If they do not have anything to put, they smear and exhibit prejudice. That is what they have done against Mr Kelty. In his defence, even the most ardent conservative newspaper pundits regard him as a gifted visionary, and say so in their columns. They may disagree with his vision, but they do not argue that he is the bogyman, a title the Opposition has tried to confer upon him in this debate. It is a disgusting and disdainful effort at playing the man and not the ball. It should be abhorred. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table an explanatory memorandum relating to the Australian Democrats amendments. I shall speak to those amendments.
—Are you moving them all together?
—Yes-I seek leave to move all the amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 2, Definitions, insert the following expressions in alphabetical order:
`gene;
genetic material;
genetically engineered organism;
genetic engineering;
organism;'.
Clause 6, page 6, lines 8 to 29, omit the clause.
Clause 18, page 11, line 4, before ``A patentable invention'', insert ``Subject to subsection (2).''.
Clause 18, page 11, at end of clause, add the following new subclauses:
``(2) Subject to the succeeding provisions of this section, a patentable invention does not include a thing that consists of or includes:
(a) gene or genes, whether derived from cells or chemically synthesised;
(b) a genome either complete or one which has had genetic material added or deleted;
(c) the altered organism (human, plant, animal or micro-organism) produced by having its genome manipulated; and
(d) the progeny of the genetically engineered organism which also carry the altered genome.
(3) If an application for such a patent is made, the Commissioner must refer the application to a committee established by the regulations.
(4) The committee may recommend that subsection (2) does not apply to the application and if the committee so recommends, that subsection does not apply.
(5) In making a decision, the committee is to have regard to criteria specified in the regulations.
(6) The decisions of the committee and the grounds for the decision shall be made public.
(7) Sub-section (2) does not limit the patenting of technologies, techniques and processes involved in the carrying out of genetic engineering.'
Clause 41, pages 18 and 19, line 15 (page 18) to line 10 (page 19), omit the clause.
Clause 42, pages 19 and 20, line 11 (page 19) to line 7 (page 20), omit the clause.
Clause 111, page 44, lines 14 to 18, omit the clause.
Clause 228, pages 81 and 82, paragraph (2)(s), line 44 (page 81) to line 14 (page 82), omit the paragraph.
Schedule 1, page 86, Dictionary, insert the following definitions in alphabetical order:
`` `gene' means the smallest unit of genetic material that specifies a single protein molecule;
`genome' means the complete complement of genetic material in a cell;
`genetic material' means Deoxyribonucleic Acids (DNA) or Ribonucleic Acid (RNA), or the genes into which the DNA or RNA is organised;
`Genetically engineered organism' means the product of genetic engineering;
`Genetic engineering' means the artificial manipulation of DNA or RNA of a single species or different species to produce a recombinant DNA;
`organism' means any animal, plant, bacterium or virus (living or dead), uni-cellular or multi-cellular;''.

In moving these amendments, which have been circulated, I am not attempting to bring the new Senate committee system into any disfavour whatsoever. I strongly support the new system and I think the working of the new system in the case of this particular piece of legislation illustrates that it will indeed produce better legislation.

First of all, while the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology was sitting there were, of course, a number of other committees sitting and several pieces of legislation were being dealt with simultaneously by those various committees and that clearly is an advantage. Secondly, the working of this particular committee procedure on this Bill allowed the exploration of the principles which I sought to have written into this legislation with the Minister and the Minister's advisers present. That has resulted in the original suggested amendments being rejected by the Minister. But subsequently I wrote different amendments seeking to fulfil the same principle but taking into account the Minister's objections. I believe that the amendments which are now before the Senate are better amendments in the sense they take in a wider range of considerations than the amendments as originally circulated. The procedure which we have adopted, I believe, will result if not in this legislation-but I hope it will in this legislation-then in other legislation being better as time goes on.

The Patents Bill 1990 is an extremely important piece of legislation, otherwise I would not have persisted with this matter. In my second reading speech I dwelt at some length on the ethical questions of the patenting of life and made the point that many people in our community feel very strongly about the undesirable nature of patenting life, life forms or anything to do with life systems, and that for that reason they sought to exclude the patenting of life and life forms from patents legislation.

Walter Gilbert, a Nobel Laureate and Harvard biologist, describes a project currently proceeding in a number of laboratories around the world, the object of which is to obtain the complete sequence of Deoxyribonucleic Acid (DNA), which describes the human being, some three billion to five billion bases long over the next 10 to 15 years so that one can completely describe that library of human genetic information. He says:
Obtaining the human genome blueprint is the ultimate answer to the commandment 'Know thyself'. It is the Holy Grail of biology.
What this legislation is about-unless amended-would allow the Holy Grail to be patented. That is the level at which many people feel about this legislation and the ethics of patenting life.
Arthur Caplan, Director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota, has also said:
It is going to be one of the key ethical challenges of the 1990s.
So, there is no doubt that in this area we are treading on extremely dangerous and shifting ground. Many of us believe that the present Bill is inadequate in this very important respect.

It is interesting to note that the Bill has been in gestation since 1979, yet-and I made this point before-it has totally ignored the very important debate that has gone on in the community in relation to the ethics and the principles which should surround the patenting of life and life forms. To that extent, it is a deeply flawed piece of legislation.

This patents legislation is new legislation which should take us forward into the next decade-a decade, in which, as Arthur Caplan has pointed out, will lie the key ethical challenges of bio-ethics, yet in its present form it is silent on that matter. It says that anything is patentable, provided it is sufficiently novel and provided it shows sufficient inventiveness. No question of ethics enters into those decisions whatsoever.

This area is one of extremely rapid change-both in the technical area and in the area of social attitudes about biomedical matters, genetic engineering and so forth. Therefore it is vital that this patents legislation contain the necessary checks and balances to reflect these changes in the technology and social attitudes as people become aware of that technology and aware of the consequences which can flow from the application of that technology, particularly the consequences that flow from the patenting, the exclusive ownership and the commercialisation of that technology. As the technology changes and as social attitudes change, it is very important that we build into this legislation a system of checks and balances which is adequate and which is capable of coping with the rapid rate of change.

Very considerable concern has been expressed about this issue at the very highest levels throughout Australia. The Anglican Church, both at the level of its general synod and and at the level of its social responsibilities committee, has expressed strong opposition to the patenting of life forms. The General Secretary of the Uniting Church of Australia, after a recent meeting of the church synod in Sydney at which this matter was raised and debated, has also written opposing the patenting of life. The Queensland synod of the Uniting Church has also supported the principle embodied in the amendments I have put forward.

The Catholic Church, through the Archbishop of Adelaide, has expressed grave concerns over what the Government is proposing. Indeed, just this afternoon, I received a further letter from a Catholic women's group expressing very considerable concern about the patenting of human life forms. Of course, a number of conservation bodies and consumer groups have also expressed considerable disquiet that the Government should countenance at all the patenting of life.

These people and organisations are also aware that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology is, at this very time, considering a number of matters related to bio-engineering and bio-medical technology. Yet this Government is apparently prepared to proceed with this legislation well before that House of Representatives Committee comes forward with its report. Why is it that the Government is seeking to close off this door before this matter has been considered by the Committee?

I will outline the present proposals and explain where they differ from my previous proposals. In the previous proposals I sought exclusively to prevent the patenting of everything from genes and modified genes to the animals and plants, viruses, bacteria and higher animals which might come to contain those genes.

During the Committee stage, the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology (Senator Button) objected to that broad proposal on several grounds, one of which did contain some merit; that was, that the patenting of bacterial vaccines, particularly live vaccines, would be prevented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Viral vaccines?
—The particular example which the Minister gave was a tuberculosis vaccine which, as the honourable senator would know, is not a virus.
—I was thinking of live polio vaccines.

—A live polio virus. I have attempted-this relates particularly to clause 18 and I point out to the Committee that the other amendments are consequential upon the amendments to clause 18 being accepted-to write in a set of amendments which would have the effect of not permitting patenting of life and life forms, but in that particular case a committee could review the application. In my explanatory memorandum I have suggested that a suitable committee might comprise people drawn from the areas of technical expertise, bioethics and consumer interests, and that such a committee would review those particular applications. In the light of community standards and in the light of the expert knowledge of the people in these various areas, the committee may then recommend to the Commissioner that this particular application be permitted.

SPEECH.PARA: Under those circumstances I have no doubt that, given the present climate of opinion about the patenting of bacterial vaccines and viral vaccines, whether live or dead, developments would be patentable. The effect of the amendment which I am seeking to insert here would merely be that some review process by an appropriate ethical type of committee be an additional criterion which would have to be met before that particular invention involving life as well as novelty and inventiveness could be patented.

Given the present climate of public opinion, those examples of applications that I mentioned before which come close to imposing considerable environmental problems, ethical problems relating to the patenting of human parts, human genes or collections of human genes or the use of those genes, would probably be recommended against and would not be patentable.

Doing it in this way, a committee would be able to take into account the changing knowledge of this particular area of bio-engineering and would be able to take into account the changing perceptions of the community, the changing standards of the community. It would provide the appropriate checks and balances with flexibility. This would allow for this very important extra dimension-that is, the ethical dimension-that worries so many people about the patenting of life to be taken into account, as many of us believe it should be.

I merely draw the Committee's attention again to the fact that the substantive part of the amendments lie in the addition of proposed subclauses 18 (2), 18 (3), 18 (4), 18 (5), 18 (6) and 18 (7) to clause 18. The other clauses are consequential upon that. I recommend to the Committee the adoption of these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that Senator Coulter's amendments are based on the premise that patenting generally is an undesirable practice and I understand that very clearly. I do not think there is anything in these amendments which would make the Opposition have any more thought than was the case last week. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree with Senator Archer to the extent that the Committee worked well but I am very disappointed to hear his other remarks and those of Senator Collins in that it seems that expediency is to take precedence over morality in this case.
—I raise a point of order. I call on Senator Coulter to retract that statement.

—Order! There is no point of order.

—My comment was directed particularly to Senator Collins. I do not know whether he wants to take exception to it. Senator Collins was saying quite explicitly that, were this amendment to be adopted, it would slow down the process. SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon, just before I came into the chamber, I received a report entitled Global Effort To Map Human Genes: Testing Scientific Cooperation. I have already pointed out that there is a massive human genome project going forward which is an attempt to completely map the total sequence of basis in the human genome over the next 10 to 15 years. The article states that, once scientists have their gene map with all the genes identified and pinpointed, they expect to be able to diagnose and treat thousands of currently incurable genetic diseases such as Down's syndrome, Alzheimer's disease, muscular dystrophy and cystic fibrosis. The report also says that the two-year-old project is beginning to stir some controversy over who will pay for the work and who will benefit from the lucrative patents expected to result from it.

That report is only brief but one of the May issues of Science has a seven-page series of articles dealing with this very difficult question of the sharing of scientific information when it comes down to the level of the human genome.
