SPEECH.PARA: I would like to start by discussing the town of Charleville. As we all know, earlier this year Charleville was struck by the greatest floods in the recorded history of that area of Queensland. In my maiden speech I commended to the Senate the efforts of the people of Charleville to rebuild their town. I said, amongst other things, that we had to ensure that they had the opportunity to rebuild their lives as they were before the floods. Over the past weekend I had the good fortune to visit Charleville, to attend a Chamber of Commerce dinner there and also to attend the opening of the St Vincent de Paul Society centre. Both these stories are very important. I believe that they are stories of hope.

One of the difficulties that I pointed out in my maiden speech in this place was that the business community of Charleville faced grave difficulties because, although credit was available to these business to keep on going, the problem was that eventually the credit would have to be repaid. For a number of weeks we heard stories of how the State Government in Queensland was going to make grants available to get business on the road again in Charleville. Unfortunately, that State Government has not come good with all its promises and many of the grants that people in Queensland and elsewhere in Australia thought would be flowing to the businesses and people of Charleville did not make it. That is a matter for some concern and is a little bit unfortunate.

The people of Charleville got on with the job of rebuilding their town and rebuilding their Chamber of Commerce. I feel it was a great honour to attend the Chamber of Commerce dinner on Saturday night-a dinner which, I hasten to add, was organised not by the Chamber of Commerce, but by six year 12 students. I think this is a fine example of what young people have to contribute to this country and to their local communities. I think those six year 12 students ought to be commended, as I believe the Chamber of Commerce in Charleville deserves to be commended for giving young Australians an opportunity to make a contribution to their local community. This, I believe, is outstanding.

Equally outstanding was what the business community of Charleville has done in terms of getting back on the road, restocking the shops, fitting out the bakery again, and ensuring that the ordinary things that we take for granted when we walk into the shops are there for the people of Charleville. Unless that exists, then those people undoubtedly will really feel the despair that the flood brought. At least they had a chance to get on with their lives.

The St Vincent de Paul Society is also making a contribution to the recovery of Charleville. On Sunday it opened its new centre at Charleville. That was very pleasing. This is a shop to which people can come and buy items with a sense of dignity. They do not feel that they are just getting hand-me-downs and unwanted clothes. They can go in in the same way that they walk into Coles, Myers or whatever. I think that is very important because these people have self-respect, as we do. It is very important that, on the road to recovery from the flood in Charleville, they should feel that they are not second-class citizens. I believe that the people of Charleville are outstanding citizens and one can judge that by their courage, determination and the contributions they have made to their local community.

The difficulty, ultimately, is that Charleville has a closed economy. There is not a lot of outside trade; the only real source of outside income is the wool industry. We all know that the wool industry is going through a very rough time indeed. Many woolgrowers are facing a 44 to 50 per cent drop in their incomes. For the people of Charleville that means a 44 to 50 per cent drop in the value of the local economy and a 44 to 50 per cent drop in the money that is available to rebuild that township. But the people of Charleville are getting on with the job. Although it is a somewhat distressing situation, they at least have tackled the problem head on and I believe that ultimately Charleville will be rebuilt again.

Another town that has suffered economic downturn and is on the road back is Kenilworth. Prior to coming down to Canberra for this recent session I had the good fortune to visit the town of Kenilworth and to see what the local people have done to rebuild the fortunes of their town as a result of the economic downturn. One of the principal industries in the Kenilworth area is dairying, which means that the local farmers contribute to the production of milk, butter, cream and cheese. For many years the Kenilworth community had a cheese factory that was operated by Kraft Foods Ltd. Approximately 18 months or two years ago Kraft decided to close down the cheese factory and that meant the loss of many local jobs. It also meant a loss of demand for the products that were made in that area. Some of the local people decided that this was not a satisfactory state of affairs. They organised to buy the factory from Kraft and are now producing quality cheese for the Australian market and, hopefully, for the international market.

I visited Kenilworth Country Foods. I inspected the facility it has there-and it is a very fine facility indeed-and I also tried the cheeses it produces. It is excellent cheese. I commend that product and the endeavours of those people to honourable senators. I hope that one day we may see Kenilworth Country Foods cheeses here in the Senate for the enjoyment of senators and staff in the relevant dining rooms. But maybe that is some way down the track.

I point out that the people of Kenilworth, like the people of Charleville, have a commitment to their local community. They have a sense of where their community is going and what they can do to contribute towards it. I believe that this is very important, very heartening and very good to see. As a Queenslander, I am proud of these people. I believe that, as Australians, all honourable senators ought to be proud of them. Accordingly, I commend the efforts of these fine Queenslanders to honourable senators and to the country as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to overseas aid and some disastrous areas of mismanagement that have flowed from the Budget decision of this Government in that regard. This week the Overseas Service Bureau (OSB), a non-government organisation, announced that it was cancelling its 1991 mid-year departure group of Australian Volunteers Abroad. This means that approximately 50 Australian volunteers will not be able to participate in development assistance work in the poor countries of the world. The cutback is directly due to cuts in Australia's overseas aid budget announced by this Labor Government in August. As well as the cancellation of the mid-year group, the size of the January group will be curtailed.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly distressed that such cuts are to take place, affecting the most active non-government organisation in the overseas development field. Ten years ago I was asked by the then Foreign Minister to chair a committee of review into the Overseas Service Bureau. As many honourable senators from that time, and some who are here now, would know, the wide-ranging recommendations in the report we brought forward were fully adopted by the Overseas Service Bureau and, indeed, by the Department of Foreign Affairs.

I still have confidence in this important organisation and in the program Australian Volunteers Abroad (AVA). I am glad to see that there is increasing interest amongst Australians in supporting and being involved in AVA. This decision, which the Overseas Service Bureau has been forced to make for the first time, is particularly saddening to those of us on both sides of the Parliament who have an interest not only in our continuing the existing level of overseas aid and development assistance to countries in our region in particular, but also in seeing that this particularly effective non-government organisation remains undiminished.

The Executive Director, Mr Bill Armstrong, said that it was an indictment that at the time when applications from well qualified and skilled Australians were up by 50 per cent and requests from developing countries seeking assistance were also increasing, Australia's volunteer program was forced to cut back. Developing countries around us in the Pacific and Asia and also in Africa will be affected by the fact that, because of aid cuts, the Overseas Service Bureau is unable to send volunteers to fill requested positions. This funding cut reduces the OSB's opportunities to provide direct development assistance to our neighbours.

I believe that this is an extremely short-sighted cutback of our aid program, which is cost effective and has long lasting benefits in terms both of the technical assistance and the enhanced relationships between countries which it provides. The Australian Government has a responsibility to follow the examples set by other developed countries and adequately fund the volunteer program. That is my view and I put it to the Senate.

Budget Paper No. 4, which outlines Australia's overseas aid program for 1990-91, says that we are maintaining in real terms the ratio of 0.33 per cent of gross national product (GNP) as the level of our overseas aid this year, but at other points it acknowledges that there is a $100m fudge in that overall statement. For instance, in Budget Paper No.1 at page 3.306, there is this sentence:
The increase reflects the fact that payments to international development financial institutions in 1989-90 were artificially low as a result of the rescheduling of $94.0m into 1988-89.

So to maintain the same level of assistance this year as compared to last financial year, when there was an artificial lowering, the Government has said that $100m less is to provided for development assistance in this year's Budget. That is also referred to on pages 14 and 36 of Budget Paper No. 4.

I want to make it entirely clear to all those in Australia who are concerned about overseas development aid that we have seen not only a failure by this Government to maintain last year's level of overseas aid but also a lowering every single year of the Hawke Government. On that point, I wish to make a comparison by reiterating the position of the Opposition with regard to overseas aid.

The Liberal and National parties have a strong commitment to Australia's foreign aid program. That commitment is based on a moral responsibility to assist those less fortunate than ourselves and a belief that this responsibility transcends national boundaries. We also believe that an effective foreign aid program is an indispensable part of an effective Australian foreign policy.

We in the Liberal and National parties continue to support as a goal and to work towards the United Nations objective of applying 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product in foreign aid. In the shorter term, however, Australia faces certain realities. The critical and very vulnerable Australian economy is the product of the Labor Government's mismanagement. Australia's role in international affairs and foreign aid in particular can be enhanced in the long term only if we restore strength to our economy. That urgent task calls for some hard and difficult decisions.

The coalition is committed to implementing an effective overseas aid program. We believe that Australia's aid program can be better targeted and more effectively implemented than that currently being administered. In achieving better targeting and implementation of Australia's foreign aid program, the criteria which should be applied to country specific aid programs include levels of national income in recipient countries, the ratio of their military expenditure to gross domestic product and their geographic location. Consistent with the broad principles of our aid program, we favour Australian aid-with the exception of humanitarian assistance-being allocated in a way that gives priority to the countries of the Asia-Pacific region.

We also believe that, in addition to being effective and compassionate, Australia's foreign aid program should have clear objectives against which performance can be assessed. With the exception of humanitarian assistance, foreign aid should be allocated on the basis of improving the economic base of the recipient country and promoting sustainable development.

The Liberal and National parties take the view that as far as possible Australia's foreign aid programs should be administered on a bilateral basis. We also believe that greater use of non-government organisations should be made in administering our aid program and that direct investment by the Australian private sector in aid recipient countries should be encouraged.

The coalition's record on foreign aid when last in government was significantly better than that of the current Labor Government. During the period of the Fraser Government-1975 to 1983-the average ratio of foreign aid to GNP was 0.45 per cent compared to the average ratio of 0.41 per cent under the Labor Government from 1983 to 1990. Furthermore, the aid to GNP ratio of 0.47 per cent in the last year of the Fraser Government contrasts markedly with the current ratio of 0.33 per cent.

There are important humanitarian, economic and strategic reasons why an effective and compassionate foreign aid program will be an important priority for the coalition parties. Our policies will reflect both the generosity that is called for and the economic responsibility that is necessary. I conclude with the observation that before the last election in the Economic Action Plan of the coalition we announced that the criteria I have referred to in my remarks tonight would lead to a temporary cut in foreign aid, and we outlined what that cut would be. We were honest with the electorate and we set out the exact areas that would be affected. We said that aid to the South Pacific and Papua New Guinea, for example, and humanitarian assistance everywhere, would not be diminished. Rather, any cuts would be in the areas that we specifically defined.

In contrast with this, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gladhanded overseas aid community groups and the churches, saying that they would not themselves be cutting. At the time there was a debate in the final weeks of the election campaign in which we said, `You cannot trust this Government. It might say now that it will keep up development assistance. We are being honest with you. To the extent that we will cut it, we have outlined it'. The paradox is that the actual cut in overseas aid by the Hawke Labor Government is the $100m that we had indicated honestly was to have been our approach initially in the first stage of coming to government after March of this year.

I make it entirely clear, honestly in this chamber and to the Australian public, that we in the Liberal and National parties can be taken at our word, and it should not be counted against us that we have defined the cloth to which our suit must be cut for the reasons that we had outlined honestly to the electorate. In contrast, we have a cut of the same dimensions-some argue more-by this Government in office, which before the last election it piously, hypocritically and misleadingly denied would be the case.

My main burden is that we ought to have a continuing need to review our overseas aid to ensure that we achieve the goals that I have referred to tonight and not to see a cynical government reducing the overseas development assistance that we would be calling for from many sides of the chamber and from the Australian community.

At the post-forum meeting, the United States was to be asked for details about whether in fact the weapons coming from Germany would be destroyed and, if so, with what timetable. New information had come to light during the Forum, suggesting that the U.S. has no binding commitment to destroy the chemical weapons coming from Germany to Johnston Atoll. According to documents which reached the press in the first week of August, a U.S. army general had told a closed meeting of the Senate Armed Services Committee in June in Washington that `virtually all the munitions . . . in Germany are maintained in a fully serviceable combat-ready condition'. He added, `This portion of the unitary stock, which is the most modern of our unitary stock, will likely be the last to be demilitarized. Storage at Johnston Island will be required for these munitions . . . partially from the point of view of when the facilities become available for demilitarisation and partially depending on the world situation.'

So these munitions are to be left there in a ready-to-go phase, until or if required by the United States Government. That is not what had been presented to the Pacific Island nations. I am sure that Mr Hawke, who is so closely aligned with the United States Government, knows that, yet he was trying to present this as quite a safe disposal method and suggesting that the Pacific Island nations were being unduly concerned about their own welfare. It is quite astonishing.

I could say a lot more. For example, I could mention the 10-year renewal of leases for bases in Australia such as Pine Gap and Nurrungar. I have spoken about those issues before. I think it is a great shame that Australia has as a Prime Minister someone who seems to be more enthusiastic about supporting the United States Government and kowtowing to it rather than to the people of Australia. I long for the day when we have a Prime Minister to stand up for the ideals mentioned at the beginning, that is, for an independent and non-aligned Australia-the very words to which Mr Hawke was prepared to be a signatory back in 1977.

I represent hundreds of thousands, probably millions, of Australians inside and outside the Labor Party who are totally disillusioned with the Prime Minister. They would prefer that he was not Prime Minister of this country, because of his actions in regard to the United States and his appearing to put United States interests ahead of our own and ahead of our neighbours in the Pacific and our neighbours in East Timor.

I regret to say that I supported Mr Hawke in 1983. I would have preferred to support Bill Hayden in that election, but I did not know then a lot of what I know now. Now, seven years on, the Labor Party is led by Mr Hawke. I believe that the Labor Party is fast running out of the principles which it has held proud for so long, which is why so many people have voted away from the Labor Party. The Democrats and Greens in Western Australia got 18 per cent of the vote between them in the March 1990 election. Therefore, I believe that we have a right to demand input, not only on environment issues, which are, of course, important to the Greens, but also on foreign affairs and defence issues, which are equally important to the Greens.

As to cynicism about the Australian Labor Party leadership, senior Government Ministers are now daring to say that the Green vote around the country is no longer important and was not significant in winning the election. I would like members of the Cabinet to ask the six marginal seat holders in Western Australia who retained their seats for the Labor Party-some of whom are in the Cabinet, incidentally, such as Mr Beazley-just how they felt on 24 March about the Greens' preferences generally flowing in their direction. I believe that I have every right to speak as an elected representative of hundreds of thousands and possibly many more people around Australia who are equally fed up with the lack of principled leadership, who see these great changes that have taken place in seven years, and who see the quick support of the American military intervention in the Gulf as just another example of our Prime Minister kowtowing to Washington. We wish that it would stop.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 June 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What obstacles are delaying the long awaited direct air link between Australia and Taiwan?
(2) Does the Australian Government realise the extent to which its negative attitude to Taiwan is resulting in a great loss of economic opportunity for increased trade between our two countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government supports the establishment of direct airlinks with Taiwan. Australia/Asia Airlines, a Qantas subsidiary, has been negotiating with Taiwan interests since early 1989 for the establishment of a direct airlink. Negotiations have had to be conducted within the framework of Australia's recognition of the People's Republic China (PRC) as the sole legal government of China and our acknowledgement that Taiwan is a province of China. Since there are no official relations between Australia and Taiwan, there can be no government-to-government agreement on a direct airlink. Nevertheless, commercial negotiations for a direct Taiwan airlink are continuing, and it is the Government's hope that a workable commercial agreement will soon be reached.

(2) The Government does not have a negative attitude towards trade with Taiwan and trade has in fact steadily increased. Bilateral trade with Taiwan has grown from $2.9 billion in 1987 to $3.8 billion in 1989, making Taiwan Australia's sixth-largest export market.

Australian interests are well-represented by the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) in Taipei, which operates under the auspices of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. The ACIO has a vigorous trade and investment promotion program and, in conjunction with the Australian Consulate General in Hong Kong, offers a visa facilitation service which, in 1989, enabled Taiwan to become Australia's second-largest source of business migrants. In March l990,-an Australian Education Centre was established in Taiwan to market Australian education services. In Australia, a Taiwan Market Service was established on 1 November 1988 to assist Australian business to identify and develop opportunities in Taiwan.

In December 1989, the Government introduced legislation designed to reassure investors from unrecognised international entities, including Taiwan, about the security of their investments in Australia. The Government recognises the importance of Taiwan as a trading partner, source of investment, tourism and migration. It has given strong support to the private sector in its efforts to expand commercial relations, including support for the negotiations to establish a direct airlink and for the ongoing efforts of Australian industry to negotiate reduced tariffs on Australian beef exports. The government has made clear its support for Taiwan, as a significant economy in the region, becoming a member of APEC, along with the PRC and Hong Kong.

The Government's policy of active support for the expansion of Australia's commercial and unofficial links with Taiwan, within the framework of our``one China'' policy, has contributed to the development of a vigorous and productive commercial relationship between Australia and Taiwan.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: South Africa: Humanitarian and Development Assistance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 June 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it correct that in the de-segregation program in South Africa, there are 13 separate cultural representative groups with their own language, culture and leadership, as well as various political groupings, PAC and INKATHA etc., whose interest and identity are to be preserved.

(2) Is it correct that the Minister, in announcing the increased humanitarian and development assistance of up to $15 million over the next 3 years, stated that the majority of the new funds is to go to the African National Congress (ANC); the only Marxist/Communist group.
(3) Why the ANC was selected ahead of the other groups.
(4) What other groups received an allocation and what amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The South African Year Book for 1989/90 (page 80) lists 12 major population groups. The South African Government has indicated that it envisages a constitutional settlement that will give legal protection to groups which wish to maintain and practise their own language and culture.

(2) On 17 May, while attending the Fifth Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Meeting on Southern Africa in Abuja, Nigeria, I announced that Australia would increase humanitarian and development assistance to South Africans disadvantaged by apartheid and to representative black groups. The funding of up to $15 million over the next three years will be channelled through the existing Special Assistance Program (SAPSAN) which is administered by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau. The majority of the new funds will be earmarked for assistance to ANC-identified humanitarian and educational activities, including the repatriation of South Africans living in exile. It is Government policy that funds will not be given direct to the ANC.

It is quite inaccurate to describe the ANC as a Marxist/Communist group. The ANC is a broadly based liberation movement, bringing together South Africans with widely differing ideological views and opinions, and including within its ranks members of the South African Communist Party.

(3) The Australian Government has long recognised the ANC as foremost amongst the authentic black leadership of South Africa. My decision to earmark for the ANC the majority of the new funds recognised the pivotal role that the ANC will play during South Africa's difficult process of social and political change. This is a position, I might add, that has also been recognised by the South African Government.

(4) No funds have been earmarked to other groups, apart from the current commitments detailed below. But, as in the past, viable proposals (as judged by AIDAB) put forward by other South African organisations will be eligible for generous Australian funding.

A substantial amount of the SAPSAN funds, including some of the amount earmarked for ANC identified activities, is likely to be channelled to non-partisan groups in South Africa, such as church organisations, educational institutions and non-government organisations within South Africa.

An example of this is the recent payment of $187,000 from the $2 million allocated for the resettlement and repatriation of exiles. These funds were channelled through the Australian NGO APHEDA to the South African Council of Churches, a non-denominational and politically neutral church body, to help set up the National Co-ordinating Committee. Non-ANC exiles will be eligible for assistance as well as ANC. The balance of the $2 million for the repatriation assistance is expected to be provided through similar apolitical channels, subject to the findings of the recent AIDAB SAPSAN Review and Programming Mission.

$2 million of the SAPSAN funds for the period 1990/91 to 1992/93 have not been earmarked for use by specific organisations, but will be used to meet ongoing commitments (set out below) and other activities as approved.
* Training in Australia for continuing students (SWAPO, PAC)
* Funds channelled through Australian NGOs

* Ongoing support to Multilateral organisations assisting South Africans disadvantaged by apartheid (Some support can be expected to continue, but the amounts and timing have not yet been determined).
NA
* Program administrative support (est.)

Assistance to South African victims of apartheid that is not``ANC identified'' is provided not only from SAPSAN funds, but also under programs arising from the meetings of the CFMSA. An example of this is support provided to the Southern Africa Advance Training Trust (SAATT). Support to other CFMSA activities such as media training and assistance to the South Africa Financial Links Monitoring Agency will continue in 1990/91.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 1 June 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since the Child Support Agency was established how many people have applied for and been granted a Supporting Parent's Benefit.
(2) Of those, how many have sought exemption from the requirement that they seek child maintenance from the non-custodial parent of their child/children.
(3) How many have been granted exemption, and on what grounds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In March 1989 Supporting Parent's Benefit and Class A Widow's Pension were merged into Sole Parent's Pension. From 1 June 1988 (the commencement date of stage one of the Child Support Scheme) to 30 June 1990, an estimated 221 000 new grants of Supporting Parent's Benefit, Class A Widow's Pension or Sole Parent Pension were made. In addition, an estimated 4000 people transferred into one of these categories from other pension types.

(2) The decision to provide an exemption from the requirement to take action to obtain maintenance in a particular case is a discretionary one, often made on the recommendation of a social worker following an interview with the client. Such an interview usually occurs when a sole parent pensioner has indicated a reluctance to take such action. Because this process does not involve the lodgment of a formal application for exemption, information is not available on the numbers of sole parent pensioners who have sought the exemption.

(3) Details of exemptions granted are held on the Maintenance Action Indicator (MAI), a record included in my Department's Pensions computing system. The MAI was introduced in November 1989. Information on exemptions is available only for current pensioners granted since the commencement of stage two of the Child Support Scheme. At 20 July 1990 there were 62 699 people receiving Sole Parent's Pension granted on or after 1 October 1989 (when stage two of the Scheme started). Of these, 13% (7344) had been granted a permanent exemption. The reasons for exemption were:
(a) where clients fear that, if they take action for maintenance, the non-custodial parent will react violently toward them or their family (1083 cases);
(b) where clients do not know the identity of the fathers of the children (2085 cases);

(c) where circumstances exist in which it would be a harmful or unreasonable imposition to expect clients to seek maintenance-for example, where the child was born as a result of rape or incest (3126 cases);
(d) where a non-custodial parent is deceased (2001 cases).
There are also exemptions of a temporary kind available to take account of:

(a) situations where the sole parent pensioner cannot take maintenance action at a particular time but where the circumstances may change and the case, therefore, is subject to periodic review- for example, where the non-custodial parent (NCP) is in gaol or overseas (990 cases) and stage one cases where the NCP's income is too low or the NCP's whereabouts are unknown (4492 cases); and
(b) a range of circumstances where the sole parent pensioner is taking action to obtain child support but this process is not yet completed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Business Hours

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The normal business hours of Regional Offices of the Department of Social Security in Queensland are 8.30am to 4.30pm Monday to Friday. However, public contact areas may be closed from 1.30pm each Tuesday.

The switchboard remains open during these closures. Any case considered to be an emergency is passed to the appropriate officer for immediate action. Any member of the public who contacts the office with a general or non-urgent inquiry is asked to leave a telephone number or to telephone the office the following day.

As the Senator was informed in the response to his letter of 10 May 1990, this arrangement was introduced to provide staff with greater opportunity to familiarise themselves with the large number of changes in Social Security legislation, to undertake training and to catch up on any arrears of work.
